Academics.Review: There is such a wide variety of options to choose from that it's had not to find your perfect niche!
Academics.Author: College Freshman

Academics.Review: I have switched majors a couple of times, but Social Sciences seems to be the perfect fit! I've had great experiences so far with all the faculty and staff from this department.
Academics.Author: College Freshman

Academics.Review: Though I am not declared, I have so far enjoyed my Public Health classes. Very interesting teachers. Classes aren't too large and grades are mostly based on tests.
Academics.Author: College Freshman

Academics.Review: There are tons of majors to choose from. Registration is definitely stressful. APs come in handy.
Academics.Author: College Freshman

Academics.Review: I love being in the B-school. They have the best facilities and the professors are great. It's not that easy to double major, but it's doable.
Academics.Author: College Freshman

Academics.Review: I love being in the B-School because they provide you with a ton of opportunities and the b-library is my favorite place to study.
Academics.Author: College Freshman

Academics.Review: I received a free application and it took only 10 minutes to fill out. I never really considered going there, originally, but it took no time at all.
Academics.Author: College Freshman

Academics.Review: Tulane offers something for everyone with over 60 majors.
Academics.Author: College Freshman

Academics.Review: Academics at Tulane are a priority of the students and staff.
Academics.Author: College Freshman

Academics.Review: All my professors are awesome and the curriculum is amazing workload is balanced.
Academics.Author: College Junior

Academics.Review: Very convenient and all my professors so far are very understanding/considerate of students
Academics.Author: College Junior

Academics.Review: I like my program because there area variety of internship opportunities nationwide and even globally
Academics.Author: College Junior

Academics.Review: I ma a Distance learning student and all my professor are amazing and the courses are very convenient
Academics.Author: College Junior

Academics.Review: Once you get the core requirements out of the way school definitely gets better. The core requirements, for the lack of a better term, suck. Although most of the professors are good, it is hard as a (for example) art major to be interested in calculus. People here are generally studious and there are multiple study areas available. They are also currently building an addition to the library.
Academics.Author: College Freshman

Academics.Review: The Business school workload is above average but manageable. Teachers are generally helpful and want you to succeed. Of course there is always that one terrible teacher. Tulane definitely has a great network of alumni in terms of jobs and internships.
Academics.Author: College Freshman

Academics.Review: Intro level classes are lame, but B school classes are great if you chose the right professors.
Academics.Author: College Freshman

Academics.Review: Business students get all the perks.  Even though I take b school classes as a sophomore, i'm really looking forward to it.
Academics.Author: College Freshman

Academics.Review: The business school is open admission.  This is good and bad, but I'm glad it was easy to get in.
Academics.Author: College Freshman

Academics.Review: This is a good school, and they will challenge you while making a degree accessible.
Academics.Author: College Freshman

Academics.Review: I am a major in Biomedical Engineering and most of the time I will have to self tutor because most of the professors in this field do not have English as their first language which makes it a bit of a struggle. I want to be a success so that i can be a plus to society, i also volunteer my services to tutor high school kids with my gift of calculus,
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: Switching majors and minors at Tulane is incredibly easy. There are also plenty of majors and minors to choose from. It is one of the only schools in the country with an in-class community service requirement, which requires you to complete a course with at least 20 hours of service. If you don't like community service, you seriously should NOT come here.
Academics.Author: College Freshman

Academics.Review: Once you get past the intro classes, many of the professors and their classes are incredible. Be engaged and reach out to your professors--they'll be more than happy to get to know you and help you out.
Academics.Author: College Junior

Academics.Review: They are usually great. Just challenging enough, but not overly difficult. Professors really care.
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: The professors are often at times lackluster and hard to reach. The curriculums are very challenging and will take you a long way in your future. The workload can be quite heavy but you can work it out around you schedule. There are plenty of studying venues on/off campus.
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: I intern at Audubon Zoo in the veterinary hospital. It is unpaid, and you have to do a three month training before you can start. You work one shift a week, for four hours. The times are pretty flexible. I am pursuing veterinary school so this is a great opportunity for me.
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: I have not yet started classes at Tulane but the professor I have been in touch with has been very helpful in answering my questions and understanding towards my concerns.
Academics.Author: Recent Alumnus

Academics.Review: Biomedical engineering is undoubtably one of the more difficult  majors at the school, but it is manageable.  It is a time-consuming workload, and the classes are challenging, but that's not to say you can't have a social life while studying it.  I'm in a sorority, and in a variety of other clubs and organizations on campus, so I have learned to manage my time and juggle my responsibilities.
Academics.Author: College Senior

Academics.Review: Most of the courses I have had at Tulane have been fair and appropriately challenging; however, there are a few professors whose classes I have found to be irritatingly difficult for the wrong reasons; lack of ability to speak proper English, not very communicative, rigid in policy, etc.
Academics.Author: College Senior

Academics.Review: There are lots of major choices at Tulane, and most of the schools designate students with an academic advisor that help them tailor their coursework.
Academics.Author: College Senior

Academics.Review: registering for classes sucks, you usually get screwed in some way. good 4 + 1 options for getting your masters. business school is a go to for most people who don't know what else to do. Classes usually aren't too big which is nice and I've had some as small as 14 students. Using the course evaluation results and ratemyprofessor.com is really important for picking classes because it sucks to get stuck with a bad professor
Academics.Author: College Freshman

Academics.Review: Professors are usually very accessible but it's very hit or miss in terms of how knowledgeable they are and how interesting they make the class. Some teachers are amazing and you'll learn a lot and others you can get an A without knowing any of the material and you come out having learned nothing.
Academics.Author: College Freshman

Academics.Review: My major is as of yet undeclared, but I am partial to the Environmental Sciences.  The courses required to satisfy major requirements are of course demanding, but also engaging with various curricula and professors.  The study abroad opportunities are plentifulfor this major, including trips to Costa Rica.  Class sizes vary, though for mathematics and some science courses (based on the ones I've taken thus far) the student:professor ratio tends to be significantly greater, sometimes a bit overwhelmingly so.  Being situated in such an ecologically diverse region, there are many internship and research opportunities here at Tulane, and feedback from friends and upperclassmen who've attended these is usually positive and indicative of personal growth.
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: I studied history, and I found that Tulane offered a wide variety of history classes. You can take upper level history classes as an undergraduate, which are both fun and challenging. In these classes you have contact with graduate students and you can get a glimpse into what is next. Certain classes had pretty heavy workloads, especially regarding papers and reading, but it was usually quite interesting material.
Academics.Author: Recent Alumnus

Academics.Review: Tulane University has great professors, both visiting and permanent. The classes were often extremely engaging and the upper level history classes I took were small which made them much more enjoyable for me. The workload could be daunting at times, but I don't see this as a negative because you are there to study. The registration process is quite easy, and as you spend more time in the university you are given priority. As a history major, I was more than fulfilled by the department at Tulane.
Academics.Author: Recent Alumnus

Academics.Review: Tulane is great for science and business majors. The liberal arts though are not on the same level.
Academics.Author: College Senior

Academics.Review: Its very difficult to get into the classes you want but so long as you are able to get into the classes most professors are amazing and willing to help. You just have to approach them.
Academics.Author: College Freshman

Academics.Review:
I am in the Science and Engineering Department, specifically a Biochemistry and Math major. They have a lot of events, especially at the beginning of the year for people who are interested in a science major. There is a group of biochemistry majors that send out emails to declared biochemistry majors about meetings, schedules, and events. Advisors are specifically assigned to students based on their area of study, and many specialize in pre-health for the science majors who plan on studying medicine. 
As a double major in the science department, my workload is heavy. I have an incredible about of problem sets to do and a lot of reading. I will say that every science professor I have had has made me more passionate about the subject than I was before I took the class.
I am personally pre-vet, and there are not as many options in internships and specific information as there are for pre-med students.
Academics.Author: College Freshman

Academics.Review: I feel like Tulane has given me a top notch education... and I have only been here for a semester. All my professors were extremely knowledgable, and my classes were challenging. Getting an A in a difficult class is one of the best feelings of accomplishment. It was difficult for me to get a class that I needed this semester, which was a pain, but it ended up working out. I will say that the workload is heavy, so expect to work hard at Tulane.
Academics.Author: College Freshman

Academics.Review: Most professors are very helpful, nice, and enthusiastic. There are great research opportunities available if that interests you (especially the Newcomb Scholars program for undergraduate women). This is a good choice if you are interested in science or business, but probably not the best for a liberal arts education.
Academics.Author: College Freshman

Academics.Review: I am extremely happy with the Ecology and Evolutionary Biology program so far! The classes all seem interesting, and the professors generally have good ratings. The biggest downfall is the fact that many biology majors in general here are pre-med. I'm not sure what my plans for the future are, except I hope to take advantage of one of the many study abroad programs in tropical regions that the school offers.
Academics.Author: College Freshman

Academics.Review: I had no trouble getting into my program. Tulane is very flexible about your programs and it's very easy to switch from one program to another and none are very exclusive.
Academics.Author: College Freshman

Academics.Review: I really like my program. I am in international development and while it is only a coordinate major, I feel like it is very valuable because I want to go into international non-profit work.
Academics.Author: College Freshman

Academics.Review: I really enjoy my internship. It's really cool and it was really easy to get. There are a lot of resources available.
Academics.Author: College Freshman

Academics.Review: As an undecided student, there are not as many options as there should be for me to explore my interests, but of the classes I have been able to take I've really enjoyed them.
Academics.Author: College Freshman

Academics.Review: A word to the wise: don't come here if you want an intellectual college experience. Kids aren't here for the academics, which I learned the hard way. Classes are much larger than Tulane advertises. Professors in many subjects are not very engaging and don't seem to care much about their students. It's a lot of work, but primarily busy work, not intellectually stimulating work. Also, there are a LOT of dumb students here. I was shocked. I know several people who are transferring because of how poor the academic scene is here.
Academics.Author: College Freshman

Academics.Review: The process for the music department is the same as at most other schools. You can either set up an audition early, or go through the open audition process to get into private voice studios. I don't know as much about the instrumental programs, but it's probably similar. Otherwise, all you have to do is enroll in classes. For the English department, all you have to do is enroll in courses. In your sophomore year, you have to go to academic advising, the heads of the departments, and your chosen faculty advisor(s) and fill out the paper work to declare your major(s), but it's a fairly simple process.
Academics.Author: College Junior

Academics.Review: I'm an Music Performance (Vocal)/English double major, and both programs are excellent. The music program is small, but the faculty are very active in the local music community, are well respected, and great teachers. The English department has wonderful, helpful professors, and many of them are leaders in their areas of study. There are even a couple of bestselling authors among the creative writing faculty.
Academics.Author: College Junior

Academics.Review: There are a lot of options for the School of Social Work. They do a great job working with you to determine where you will be placed and to make the process as painless as possible. For the Master's level, the internship lasts one year with one placement. You work 3 days/week for a total of 22 hours. There are not many, if any, teaching assistant positions available.
Academics.Author: College Junior

Academics.Review: The public health and international development majors are awesome at Tulane. International development is really unique, there aren't many, if any other schools that offer it.  Tulane is also very known for its Public Health program.  The professors for these subjects really know what they're talking about.  My public health professor is going to Ethiopia next semester for a public health project, and my international development professor has worked all over the world in international development projects.
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: Languages are not great, but sciences are really good here.  Some of the labs are a little lacking in equipment, but the science professors are incredibly intelligent.  The Public Health program for undergrads is great, and the International Development department is unique in the US and has the amazing Payson Center.
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: Anthropology is a fantastically diverse major and field. At Tulane, the Anthropology classes generally cap out at 10-20 students per class. This creates a very personable and interactive atmosphere. Nearly all of the classes are seminars and not lectures. This means that the classes offer the space for your personal input and interaction to learn the material as a group rather than simply being presented with information to memorize. Most of the classes involve paper analysis' of the material you have been learning that ask for your own interpretation and analysis of the topic at hand. The professors are very warm and inviting and allow for great relationships to be developed that if utilized can be extremely beneficial in the anthropology realm after graduation.
Academics.Author: College Senior

Academics.Review: They have a lot of different majors here and almost everyone double majors.
Academics.Author: Recent Alumnus

Academics.Review: Look at Prerequisites Before Deciding ‚Äì Though I really enjoy my Evo and Eco Biology Major, looking back I would probably have chosen to be a cell bio major because the requirements for that major better fit into the prerequisites I need to complete for veterinary school.
Academics.Author: College Senior

Academics.Review: So there isn't an education major which is annoying for many reasons. First, no TEACH grants until you're a post-bac. Second, you can't do your student teaching during your last semester like you normally would. You have to stay an extra semester or an extra year. But it's great because during undergrad you spend a lot of time in schools, in classrooms, getting to see and learn what is happening in New Orleans schools. Which is pretty frickin important.
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: Literally Just Go Talk to a Professor ‚Äì It might be different for me because I'm in the Liberal Arts College, but Tulane is great about that kind of thing--declaring majors and taking what classes you want to take.
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: Small Department = More Opportunities ‚Äì I'm a Film Major at Tulane.  Although we don't have a film school like USC or a grand film department as some other schools, our film department is very unique and helpful.  Since the department itself is small, I have a better chance of establishing great relationships with staff and professors.  Our department heads have a huge network in the industry so it is easy to get jobs/internships and meet lots of important people.
Academics.Author: College Junior

Academics.Review: Always There for You ‚Äì The professors are very knowledgeable about their subject matter and only want the best from their students.  If you do your part (going to class, studying, office hours, etc) the professor will be glad to help you...even for recommendations for study abroad, jobs, etc.
Academics.Author: College Junior

Academics.Review: Learning to Learn ‚Äì When I came to Tulane I was basically positive I wanted to major in Social Work or Policy. But, after taking a few different classes and working through my Liberal Arts course requirements, I found that Art History and Sociology interested me in a way that the Social Work program did not. The Art History classes are interesting and the professors are so bright, I truly enjoy going to class and completing the readings. The program requires you to take classes from all different genres of Art History, which was initially irritating, but I discovered that I really enjoyed some classes that I thought I would hate. Sociology is an entirely different kind of learning, so it provides a nice break from an all Art History course load. To be honest the material is less interesting, and it's really hit or miss in terms of good professors, but it's fascinating to take a sociology course in a city like New Orleans. You get hands-on experience and outlooks that are really on available in this city. Hopefully I'll get accepted to Teach for America and be able to get experience as a teacher before applying to grad school! If I could do it all over again I would absolutely would; I feel like I have allowed myself to take time to learn what I wanted to learn and not what my parents or anyone else thinks I should be learning.
Academics.Author: College Junior

Academics.Review: Public Health ‚Äì Most majors at Tulane are really comprehensive, respected programs that are (mostly) manageable. Obviously, majors like chem or engineering are going to be intense, but that's pretty standard at any top school. The school of Public Health is well-known and a very good program. It has a 4+1 Master's program and a grad school in addition to the undergrad.
Academics.Author: College Freshman

Academics.Review: not a wide range ‚Äì not a wide range of choices but everything (besides math and science classes where some teachers speak with an accent or talk to the board or don't care) is A+
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: Again I emphasize the availability of scientific research on campus.
Academics.Author: College Junior

Academics.Review: No Difficulties With Admission for Major ‚Äì Major specific admissions, as far as I know, are not required at Tulane.
Academics.Author: College Freshman

Academics.Review: English Major ‚Äì Being an English major at Tulane grants me a large amount of freedom. The major has a few basic requirements that are not extremely difficult to fulfill, meaning that I am free to explore other subjects. There are a wide variety of English classes available and many talented professors teaching them.
Academics.Author: College Freshman

Academics.Review: The professors at Tulane are very good. Many of them are available for office hours and will gladly arrange extra hours for students in need. They are engaging and truly care about the well being of their students
Academics.Author: College Freshman

Academics.Review: I love it here! don't know why anyone would go anywhere else
Academics.Author: College Freshman

Academics.Review: Disclaimer: I'm a Cell and Molecular bio major, so I don't really know about the other departments. My department is filled with brilliant teachers who (for the most part) care about their students' success. If you're looking for a college that gives half the class A's and the other half B's, don't come here. Most classes either aren't curved (higher level classes anyway) or are curved so that only 15 or 20% get A's. I got B's in most of my classes even though I worked really hard. Still, I feel like my undergrad education has amply prepared me for medical school, and I'm thrilled to have attended such a great school.
Academics.Author: College Senior

Academics.Review: Avoid Foreign Teachers ‚Äì Almost without exception any class taught by a foreign professor sucks because they can't communicate ideas clearly nor are they willing to put the effort in trying. There are too many of these professors at Tulane, unfortunately.
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: Just Watch Out for a Few Math and Chem Professors ‚Äì Soooo many BEAUTIFUL places to study, both on campus and not far off. There are some not so great professors, won't lie, but for every bad teacher there is a through and through amazing teacher who makes class interesting and helps makes boring facts stick better.
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review:
CollegeProwler only allows for one heading under the major category, so I selected my first major. In reality, I'm a double major focusing on Political Science as well as Creative Writing. Tulane makes it easy for students to pursue two or even multiple areas of interest, to the extent that the majority of people I know are double majors as well.

As to Creative Writing and Political Science specifically, thus far I have no complaints. My absolute favorite Professor ever taught an Expository Writing class that really opened my eyes and I've reached nickname terms with one of my Political Science professors. The opportunities available in the Political Science field especially are amazing - you can run internships, take classes with notable New Orleans political greats, and even take a class under famed political consultant James Carville. The curriculum is, as you'd expect from a self-proclaimed "Southern Ivy," not lax in anyway, but it allows a lot of wiggle room for extracurricular activities as well.
Academics.Author: College Junior

Academics.Review: An Academic Guide ‚Äì I am an incoming freshman at Tulane University, and while all of my friends who will be attending other universities in the fall are frantic about their schedules, I am calm and at ease.  When visiting Tulane, I met with an academic advisor, who instructed me as to which courses to take for both my major and a pre-med track.  Later that same day, I registered for classes and could not be happier with my schedule.
Academics.Author: College Freshman

Academics.Review:
Many Options and Resources Available ‚Äì The liberal arts major is already flexible, but the different topics of study are wide. 
Professors are eager to help students who want to succeed, but as always students must seek resources on their own.
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: Gives You a New Outlook on Life ‚Äì I came to Tulane University because of its great Biomedical Engineering program and because it gives out great scholarships (at least half to most people). I ended up switching to a different science major but one thing the university and professors have offered is the opportunity to actually go out and get to know the city and volunteer.
Academics.Author: College Senior

Academics.Review: International Development ‚Äì The professors are extremely involved in what they teach. They have a lot of experience. The classes are taught by multiple professors who are experts in the areas they teach on. Grades are mainly based on a few papers and the midterm and final. The papers are relatively easy to write but require a certain amount of research and interpretation.
Academics.Author: College Freshman

Academics.Review: Some Good Some Bad ‚Äì For me its just like high school, I have a few amazing professors and a few really horrible professors. I love my business class, the teacher is funny and interesting and cares about her students. I also love my theater class, my teach is brilliant and entertaining, and I have learned more from his class than I did in 4 years of high school theater. On the other hand I have some professors who don't challenge me at all and whose classes are a joke, and some where the teacher is so removed from the class that they can't see how bored the students are. I here the classes are better in the honors program.
Academics.Author: College Freshman

Academics.Review: Beginning a Business Degree at a.B. Freeman School of Business ‚Äì My max hours as an undergrad: 19. Most of the hours are spent covering prerequisites until qualifying for upper level business courses. Everyone in the A.B. Freeman School of Business is Microsoft certified, and there is a computer course taken each year enrolled that is tailored to suit the course load. Professors are easy to access and make genuine efforts to connect with students.
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: The workload at Tulane is challenging, but not to the point of being exhausting. You do need to work for grades, but you are not constantly pushed over the edge for an A in each class.
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: I love our campus and the community events that occur (ie fridays on the quad)
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: New Orleans is a great city with tons to do.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: It's an awesome place to spend your college years.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: The city is full of things to do and awesome people, however if you are one of the few students who doesn't come from a massive city like NY, DC, or LA, and appreciates being able to get the hell outta dodge when you feel like it, being stuck in the big city as a freshman without a car can feel claustrophobic at times. But if i'm gonna be stuck in a big city, i can't imagine a more awesome and fun one than this!!!
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: The city of New Orleans is a very interesting place, fun for visitors and college however I do not see myself living here after college.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Lots of people go to the gym (Reily), there are always people studying in the LBC or dorms, people hang out in the dorms and common rooms all the time, there is a very social atmosphere. But you can also have a very studious atmosphere when you want it.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: New Orleans offers an unparalleled college experience. There is literally ALWAYS  something fun happening. There are always cool concerts at the House of Blues, fun college bars on every street corner, and of course Bourbon Street.  There is also a bowling alley right next door to campus and a beautiful park and golf course across the street.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: New Orleans is great. So much to do.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: I love reily. The library is under construction...
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: New Orleans is one of the best things about Tulane! There's always something going on, and the city has such a great history and culture. Loyola is right next to Tulane, but students don't usually interact. However, you can use your meal swipes at Loyola's dining hall (Luff) as well as their Subway and Starbucks.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: New Orleans is wonderful and amazing and ridiculously beautiful and fun, but it isn't the safest city (highest murder rate in the country!). You should be fine if you stay aware though :)
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: New Orleans is one of the most amazing cities you will ever come across. It has so much culture and spirit and it really integrates well with our school. There is always somewhere new to explore and it never gets old.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: New Orleans is an amazing city to spend four or five of the most exciting years of your life. There are always things going on around campus and all over the city. It can be difficult and expensive to get around the city given that public transit is not the best. New Orleans is know as a dangerous city but the area surrounding Tulane is not a necessarily dangerous area of the city. Also there are simple things students can do to safe when in the surrounding area. I can't imagine a better city to spend my college years than New Orleans.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: NOLA is the best; there's always something to do that's within walking distance or accessible by street car/taxi.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Love New Orleans, always something happening, great food, music, nightlife.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Come on, this is New Orleans!
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Everything is easily accessed. I don't have to worry about not being able to work out.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: There is a mall nearby and the entertainment shuttle can take you there (and also to a movie theater and walmart), lots of cultural things in the French Quarter. Safety-wise, some parts of New Orleans are notoriously dangerous (9th Ward, etc.) but just stay alert and you'll be fine. Crime near campus isn't THAT bad but it still is present. There is a nice shopping street (Magazine St.) nearby with lots of resteraunts and little boutiques.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Beautiful area, removed enough from the city for a calm, peaceful atmosphere with a local population. There is plenty to do in the neighborhood (shopping, dinning, etc) and it is lovely to walk through. Transportation into the city and other parts of the area is very accessible.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: great scenery and green spaces to study and hangout with friends. many people will study in communal areas on nice days- which is basically always
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Its impossible to not be able to find something to do any day of the week.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: New Orleans is a great city with lots of things to do. However, one must take precaution when going out (e.g., not going out alone, not carrying a lot of money, etc.)
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: New Orleans is a one of a kind city. You cannot go wrong here.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: I believe that Tulane offers various global educational and learning opportunities for students.
Campus.Author: College Senior

Campus.Review: There is always something to do in New Orleans, whether it is a festival, a bar on frenchman or bourbon, the aquarium, zoo or shopping on the riverwalk. Not to mention the variety and quality of food is nothing short of amazing.
Campus.Author: College Senior

Campus.Review: There's always something to do in New Orleans. My friends and I are never bored because there's always somewhere to go or something to see. Even if you don't have a car it's easy to get around by streetcar.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: The school offers shuttles and there is always the street car
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Get a laptop otherwise the labs are pretty average.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Parking on campus is super overpriced, and TUPD gives out tickets like they're candy.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: The phrase "only in New Orleans, only at Tulane" says it all. At times it almost feels like you're in another country. Living in New Orleans for four years is an incredible unique and valuable experience. From Mardi Gras to all of its festivals, its food to its bars, and its parades to its culture, New Orleans is a city unlike any other.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: It baffles me how difficult it is at times to get a cab in New Orleans. The streetcar is more of a city icon than anything else, as it is constantly down for repairs and unreliable. As far as the buses go, they also tend to be unreliable and are difficult to figure out.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: Riley (the campus gym) is wonderful, and even has an outdoor pool for student use!
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: Business school students definitely get some extra pampering, which can be frustrating at times.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: You can probably find something off campus.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Amazing weather, just insanely humid.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: I've never had a problem with the wifi. I'm also in the B-School so free printing.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: The weather is beautiful and sunny one day, than pours rain the next day. But 70% of the time its great weather.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Don't need a car freshman or sophomore year living on campus, but its always nice to have one.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review:
The Tulane shuttles can be a little slow at times, but they'll take you almost anywhere - downtown/uptown campus, Walmart, Target, Clearview Mall, Lakeside Mall, Whole Foods, Fresh Market, International Market...

The streetcar is slow and unreliable. NORTA says it runs every 15 minutes. That is a bold faced lie. Buses are faster than streetcars, but don't expect them to be on schedule, either.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: New Orleans weather is fantastic. It's usually sunny and 70+. Bring your rain boots/jacket, though, you'll need them.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: Macs. Macs everywhere. If you want to finish your work on your own time and relatively stress-free, though, you're going to need your own computer. Most of the students have their own, and it can be annoying to have to wait for a computer in PJ's/the library/the b-school or wherever you want to study.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: Not the best, not the worst. Taxis are accessible for the most part. The street car takes a long time to get from Uptown to Downtown.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: New Orleans is AMAZING! It's so unique and interesting, there are so many things to do like concerts, museums, galleries, restaurants, bars, clubs, sports games.. the list goes on and on.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Sunshine most of the time
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: It's expensive and if you park illegally you WILL get a ticket
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Safe rides is pretty slow but a decent option. Taxis and the streetcar are very unreliable.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: It does get cold in the winter, but despite the humidity the weather's beautiful.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: You get a certain amount of free printing every semester. Computers in the library can fill up easily. Wifi is okay.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: There are shuttles but its very time consuming and not always reliable.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Its New Orleans. It can be PERFECT. or... Humid BLAZINGLY HOT or Humid, Windy, and Cold.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: To the schools defense, we are in a dense residential area without a lot of public parking or a place to but a parking garage other than the one we have. Parking is expensive and exploring the city without a car is either vary time consuming or very expensive.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: The city of New Orleans is pretty amazing. So much amazing culture and so many awesome festivals and foods. Decent shopping (in Metarie and Downtown that is) Can be unsafe however if you don't watch yourself. In addition, Tulane kinda traps you in a bubble by not allowing cars on campus for freshmen. For instance, people have to plan to go to somewhere as simple as Wendy's and spend money on a cab (see what I mean). But however, Lets just say there is a definite reason Tulane includes New Orleans in their promotional slogan.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Some are getting older.  Riley is pathetic for a collegiate gym.  The LBC is new and modern, its amazing.  The classrooms are alright, i wish they had smart boards instead of chalk though.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: If you're from somewhere cold, it's going to take you a while to get used to the weather down here. Be prepared for the bipolar weather in the South where it's 75 one day and we have a snow day (without any snow) the next.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Tulane definitely needs to work on the parking situation, but it's understandably difficult in a city like New Orleans. Just don't park in the neighborhoods behind Tulane because you'll definitely get a $40 ticket.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: It's literally impossible to ever get bored in New Orleans.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: The streetcar was under construction in front of Tulane for a while which was annoying, but now it's back up and running all the way down to Napoleon like usual. Lots of stuff is walking distance too.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: There are convenient computer labs in the coffee shops and a few in the academic buildings, and you get a printing budget that I've never used all of.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review:
We are literally located RIGHT NEXT TO Loyola University New Orleans (literally right next door). We can use their cafeteria, and they can use ours. A little weird, but it's pretty cool.

There's always plenty of things to do off campus, but you really have to invest the time and energy to find those things.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: If you decide to go downtown, unless you have a car, you must take the streetcar. It's historic and beautiful and fun, but it takes a really long time to get where you need/want to be. You really have to plan your trips ahead of time. Tulane also has shuttles that can take you for free different places, but the schedule of those pick-ups and drop-offs is extremely bizarre. Say you want to go to Target. The shuttle will take you there (for free!), but you might have to stay there for 4-5 hours in order to take the free shuttle to get back on campus.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: It is VERY hot and humid in the spring and summer months, and you have to either deal with it or embrace it. It really just depends on who you are and whether you like feeling like you are swimming when you step outside.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: There are always some problems with connecting to the networks.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Very residential area of new orleans. Public transportation makes it easy to get to more exciting places like the quarter or magazine street but it can be sometimes be a drag. Love the neighborhood, coffee shops around are my fave
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Nothing better than tanning in February.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: they work on and off
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: its unpredictable, but i love it here
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: The overall atmosphere of this ancient city is just breathtaking. I personally loves it
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Its great-- especially in the fall and spring. The december and january weather is a little cold, and when we first get to school in august, it is incredibly hot and humid.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: I have my own computer, and I use it all the time. I cant imagine not having my own computer, but there are computer labs around campus, and the computers are all really nice. There are macs and PCs.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Awesome-- you see people from all different backgrounds as soon as you step off campus, and there is a whole city to explore.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: During hurricane season it can be touch  & go. It's super hot and humid in the summer, but there are mild winters.
Campus.Author: College Senior

Campus.Review: There are a good number of computers on the downtown campus that are usually available.
Campus.Author: College Senior

Campus.Review: The weather can be bipolar at times, like it is everywhere else in the world. But, NOLA weather is fabulous. It is warm and sunny. The only downfall is the extreme humidity and heat at times.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Usually people have access to their own computers but if they don't, there are multiple places where there is computer access.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: NOLA is love. You can only understand this environment if you have experienced living here. It is an experience unlike no other and I highly suggest that everyone visit NOLA at least once in his or her life.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Unlike in high school, the question of "is there something to do tonight?" never comes up. In New Orleans there's always something to do. If the frats are not having any parties then you can take the streetcar in front of campus to downtown where every night there is something fun going on.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: I get very fast internet speeds when I use an ethernet cord in my room
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Humid and warm!! Never too cold - perfect perfect perfect.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: New Orleans is the best city in the entire world. I don't even feel the need to say much beyond that other than the fact that many students never leave.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Suggested you bring your own printer and computer for convenience, the library is annoying to go there for every print.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Just visit New Orleans and youll get it.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: no transportation to the airports or train station but buses that go around the city everyday with schedules posted online
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: The city draws a lot of people. It's pretty different than most cities.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: It's the great. The buildings are beautiful and the gym is large.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Everyone brings a laptop. There is an Apple store in the LBC
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: One large parking garage or risk it on side streets.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Its New Orleans so the local atmosphere is totally unique from any other university
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: It's aimed towards working students. I really enjoy the teachers and the help that office staff offers. My advisor is Great!
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: I don't know because I go to class and then leave. I don't try to hang and socialize.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: I love that there is always access to computers and there is no charge to print.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: The weather does not affect my experience. The weather changes a lot but as long as it is comfortable in the building, I'm ok.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: For those of us who love the rain, weather at Tulane could not feasibly get better.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: The campus is gorgeous and staff is friendly and gracious.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Tulane sits in the Garden District, about a 30 minute trolley ride away from the heart of New Orleans. The city's unique culture provides an array of opportunities for students to experience superb food, music, and a rich history.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: I have never had a problem with any of the facilities at Tulane. I actually love the business school and think it is the best building on campus.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: I wouldn't say that Tulane is the best school, but being in a city like New Orleans helps the experience a lot.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: New Orleans is a great city and there is always something going on. They have some of the best food and music festivals in the world.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: You really only need to use taxis or the street car if you venture off campus. The street car is amazing and can get you to some of the best parts of the city.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: There are many computer labs on campus especially in the libraries with the latest PC's and Macs available to use. Printing on campus, network reliability and speed, and wireless access are wonderful and fast. If there are problems, tech support does everything in their power to help fix it and as quickly as possible.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: New Orleans has bipolar weather. During the winter months, one week can be extremely cold but the next week can be sweltering hot. It is mainly hot throughout the year, but it also rains quite often. The local weather does not affect campus experience much except for hurricane threats. If a hurricane is on its way, we have to evacuate which is a unique type of campus experience on its own.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Parking is very hard to find on and off campus. Permits are also very expensive.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Computers are abundant at Tulane and teachers utilize technology in the best way.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: New Orleans is very rainy and can sometimes damper a day or social plans, but it is easy to deal with.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Tulane conducts a Fridays at the Quad event every Friday with free food and merchandise.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Libraries and on-campus events are the best at Tulane.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: The social scene is nothing short of frenzied at Tulane.  The student population, is not very big, but not so small that you will know everyone.  There is always a party going on either at someone's house, or somewhere else in New Orleans.  You will never be bored unless you want to be.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: The campus is gorgeous and feels like a paradise to me with warm weather and palm trees.  Some buildings are dated, but the architecture is nice.  The gym is very nice and comprehensive.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Summers are a little hot but after September the weather is beautiful.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Despite some of the run down freshman/sophomore dorms, the facilities are extremely well kept and are always being renovated.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: It is extremely easy to get around the city and surrounding areas by the campus. Tulane offers free shuttles to different malls and areas of the city. City buses also run to the campus. The famous St. Charles street car also stops right outside the front of the campus.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: This is New Orleans. There is a festival every day of the year. The city and area surrounding the school offer a vibrant atmosphere with a party, concert, and activity for everyone.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: It's NOLA, what's not to like?  There's everything and more here.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Its NOLA, the weather here is great.  A little too hot to start off the year but around now it is perfect.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: On campus shuttles are free and convenient .  Cabs run frequently but are unreliable.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Not the best, not the worst.  They're good for a school that was nearly wiped out by a hurricane almost a decade ago.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Most kids have macs but a few have PC's.  There's a technology store in the LBC.  No complaints.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Parking cost a lot, and it's only for upperclassman.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Because it's New Orleans, it rains often and is always humid. But it's warm and shorts and flip flops are ok for a majority of the semester.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: New Orleans has the best community outside of campus. Our relationship to the nearby university is minimal, however. So many museums, clubs, shopping centers, festivals.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: There is an on-campus garage but parking permits are expensive. You have to be at junior credit standing or above to have a car on campus. Parking near dorms is full bu available.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: The computers on campus are outdated and slow, its most beneficial to bring your own if you would like to excel. personally, I prefer my own computer
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: I personally never had much of a problem finding a parking spot, but the parking garage is kind of far away and the spaces are tiny. You can only park actually on campus (spots other than the garage) after 5 and on the weekends. If you park where you aren't supposed to you WILL get a $40 ticket. Also, parking permits are way too expensive.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: Tulane's buildings are very new and nice, and the historical buildings are mostly renovated very nicely. There is always air conditioning in every building, which is a big deal in New Orleans. There is ample study space in various buildings and the school seems to add more every year. We have a lot of campus programming, including a free concert with free food every Friday afternoon featuring local bands. Big name comedians and musical artists play in our auditorium every year for free or a very small ticket price. Previous acts include Janelle Monae, The Whitest Kids U Know, and Nick Offerman.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: Parking is difficult and there are not enough spots
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Safe ride is pretty useful, they pick you up from a certain mile radius around campus and you can call whenever.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: In New Orleans, there is always the potential for flooding when it rains and the humidity is extreme. However, the winters are mild here, summers are hot, and spring and autumn are beautiful.
Campus.Author: College Senior

Campus.Review: This is more about the city then the school. New Orleans is a completely unique place to go to college and if you get out of the bubble you can get yourself involved in pretty much anything. There are awesome volunteer opportunities, constantly active music scene and a good amount of other cultural events and outs of festivals throughout the year
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review:
The campus is beautiful and there are plenty of activities. The only thing preventing an a+ is that our modern art sculptures on the academic quad are stupid (we have one of testicles which is not even the worst loo
king)
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: Usually sunny and everyone is out on the quad, but when it rains... IT RAINS! It floods and you better have an umbrella and some rain boots or you're soaked.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: I think the cost is completely outrageous, especially considering that the majority of students come from out of state and therefore either fly or drive their car down, which is also costly. There is one large parking garage, but it is in the corner of campus and far from academic buildings. Street spots have limited hours, or are reserved for staff, and seem to be few in numbers. However, since the school is located in a city, I don't see the need for a car. A bike is much more practical.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: It is very easy to get away from campus and into the city of New Orleans. The street car passes right by the front of campus on St. Charles. There are Tulane shuttles everyday that run to Walmart and a grocery store. On the weekends there are Tulane shuttles that run to two different malls which have many popular stores including Target. Both of these shuttles are free with your Tulane ID. There is also a service called Enterprise Car Share which allows students to rent a car whenever they need for $10 an hour. There are two or three cars right on campus so they are super accessible.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Spots fill up quickly at Tulane University so its probably best if you park elsewhere and catch the nearest trolley heading to campus.
Campus.Author: College Senior

Campus.Review: There are shuttles that run on the weekend every hour that will take you to Target, the mall, and Whole Foods. It is completely free and really awesome. There are also Tulane buses that run everyday that go to places like Walmart and other places. The street car is right in the front of campus and is $1.50 each way, however it is a tad slow. Taxis are another option which get you to your destination quickly, but are kind of expensive unless you're sharing a cab.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: The weather is really awesome. You kind of get the best of both worlds because it is usually hot in the summer and spring and the winter gets chilly but not cold. The only bad thing is that when it rains is floods so make sure you have all the essential rain gear.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: There is a garage which most students park in and I think it is around $500 but that is just a guess. There is this one parking police that goes around and looks for every car that doesn't have a parking pass and will give lots of tickets. But in all honesty there is not much need for a car if you are living on campus.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: The main Tulane campus is uptown, there are lots of things to do uptown that you really don't need to go say like downtown or to the French Quarters.  During the spring and fall there is some sort of festival every weekend, there is plenty to do and places to go.  There are always excellent shows(live concerts and Broadway plays) to see.  The various types of cuisine in NOLA is abundant and oh so good.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: There's a lot to do in New Orleans, the crescent city. Sports games, music, museums, the French Quarter, amazing restaurants, the bars, & nightlife in general. New Orleans is amazing. You can take a street car anywhere, (when they're not working on the tracks), and if you take the time to get off campus you will experience so much life here.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Humidity! If you don't like it, get used to it or don't go to a school in New Orleans. It's often sunny though, and when it's not it's rainy. It doesn't get very cold but when it does it's a different feel because it's a humid cold.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: They have macs in the library and some labs, which is awesome. (All college students love macs) The labs without macs still have very nice computers with the necessary programs to get work done (ie word, powerpoint, excel, internet explorer, firefox)
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Beautiful, sunny weather most of the year; a few months it's terribly humid, and then there's hurricane season, but for the most part, there is more time to enjoy the sun than not.
Campus.Author: College Senior

Campus.Review: When it rains, it pours, and the summer months are incredibly hot. However, the winter months are mild and we don't have to worry about snow!
Campus.Author: College Senior

Campus.Review:
Good quality and satisfying.
Only bad part is that the number is not enough to use when the library is full.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: I attend the Madison, MS campus and the parking is great. It does not matter what side of the building I park on it is very close.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Transportation is AWESOME! Tulane has shuttle services available 7 days a week that take you to an array of locations. New Orleans public transportation is also very convenient and useful, but may dwindle in the late hours of the night. Tulane's safe ride also provides transportation within a mile radius of the school, which can prove to be very useful.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: You live right on the gulf so the weather could be anything!
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Internet and computer access has never been problematic. There is a strong wifi signal on every corner of campus, and the computer labs and library is filled with the very newest Mac and PC computers which are open to any student any time. Each department has their own computer lab, with specific programs, open to students with appropriate majors. Printers are available all over campus and all students are given money at the beginning of each semester, allocated specifically for printing. Still, however, I would recommend bringing your own printer for much greater convenience.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: Public transportation is good around campus. The area isn't huge, as most people walk or ride bikes to get around. They do, however, have a program called SafeRide in which a free ride is delivered to you at your request-almost any time of night. Transportation around the city of New Orleans is slightly more complex though. Tulane is nestled in the uptown area of the city, and to visit the historic downtown area can be pricey. There is a street car that will get you there in about 20 minutes for about $1.25, but you can be waiting for as long as 0:45 minutes before a car arrives at your stop. The streetcar runs for most hours of the day and night. Other than that, a taxi cab may be your only option sometimes and can run you $20-$40 depending on how far youre going.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: The off-campus transportation is not too bad. Street cars and busses are only $1.25 for a one-way ride, and as long as you're not on a strict time schedule, they're great. Cabs can get expensive, and are often hard to catch. The drivers, knowing you're a college kid, will often try to rip you off, so you have to be careful about that. As for on-campus transportation, we really don't have a ton. There are some Tulane shuttles to the downtown campus and to Walmart and stuff like that, but they go to very specific places and take a while to get anywhere.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Tulane prides itself on its service learning requirements for students which get them involved in 20 and 40 hour community service activities that complement their classes. It is still not fully developed because long-term partnerships are rare, but the program is constantly improving.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Reily: Our athletic center rocks! Better than any other gym I've ever belonged to and has everything imaginable from pools and suanas to free exercise classes. People from the NOLA community are also members and recently students spotted Sofia Vergara and Will Ferrell working out
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review:
Sometimes my roommate cannot get any wireless access from her side of the room while mine is fine. Different areas have stronger connections and sometimes the internet just stops working.
Printing: You get a fair amount of free printing for semester and the Hillel building also has free printing which is extremely helpful.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Coming from the northeast, the warmth is so enjoyable! In the winter it never gets freezing. The only downfall for some people is the frequent rain, but when I remember to wear my rainboots, I love the rain too.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: New Orleans public transportation is not known for its speed or reliability. Most students get around by taking the streetcar, which will get you where you need to be "eventually." At first the streetcar ride is charming, but once you have lived here for a while and actually need to be somewhere on time, it can be a pain. Also, the line has been under construction for the past year, and progress is happening at a glacial pace. You need to take a bus and then get a free transfer to the streetcar to get downtown. A 15 minute drive ends up being a 45 minute endeavor. It's not as bad as it sounds, but no one should come here expecting the timely transportation of other cities. You can also take the bus, which travels at a more normal speed, but students barely use it. Cabs are fairly priced, but during certain times of year, the lines can be so busy that it's impossible to get one. You always end up where you need to be, but the process can be aggravating.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: The computer labs could be a bit crowded and the computers were sometimes slow, but you are given quite a bit of money for printing every year which is a nice perk. The wifi varies depending on where you are on the campus, but overall it works fairly quickly. I had a laptop throughout my four years there, and it definitely is nice but not completely necessary. Don't worry about buying your own printer, you shouldn't need one.
Campus.Author: Recent Alumnus

Campus.Review: The Reily Center (school gym) has modern facilities and offers a wide array of exercise classes. There is a small outdoor pool and an indoor lap pool. However, the gym can get quite crowded and you sometimes have to wait for machines.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: The Prevention Research Center at Tulane offers many opportunities to get involved with research and has many ties to local organizations.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: You can't have a car for your first 2 years, which is inconvenient. However, The street car will take you down town for a total of $2.50, as long as you are willing to wait for it.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: mostly macs, high tech, but crowded during finals-get there early
Campus.Author: College Senior

Campus.Review: Parking on campus is very expensive. Very. Expensive. And you can only park in the designated garage because if you park in a space anywhere else on campus you get a $40 ticket. Only faculty can park there. I see cars with tickets and boots on them all the time. Also, your ticket fine is lower if you park on the quad than if you park in an unauthorized space. It doesn't make sense.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: There are shuttles that pick you up to go to the downtown campus and to multiple shopping locations far from campus--and they're free. At night there is SafeRide which will pick you up within a mile from campus and bring you safely back to your dorm or off-campus housing--for free. Anything you need is within walking or biking distance, but of course there are the shuttles. If you have an off-campus internship of service program scheduled, you can set up your own shuttle or van to take you there for free. There is an airport shuttle, but it costs money. Taxis are easy to get, and the streetcar is only $1.25.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: As a freshman, I am not allowed to have my car on campus. Coming from Louisiana, sometimes I feel very restricted; however, the streetcar/buses are available to bring you downtown or to a suburb for the mall. Parking passes seem pretty pricy, but I'm sure they're no more expensive than other private universities. The parking on campus is pretty bad, though. The roads are terrible! Also, the reason that freshmen are not allowed to have cars on campus is because there is such limited availability for parking. Tulane is a growing university; however, there is no place for it to expand. Overall, I do not think having a car on campus is completely necessary. Yes, it does make grocery shopping easier, but my two feet (and my friends' cars) are enough for me!
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Library and Recreation could definitely use some updating but overall Tulane offers great facilities with everything you need
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: The New Orleans atmosphere is great and the activities and cultures are really good.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: The computer lab is a helpful tool. They are fast and reliable
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: There are plenty of computers located all over campus. Many residence halls have computer labs inside which is very convenient around exam time. Computers are in short supply around exam time though so be prepared to use your own computer. Tulane WiFi can be a bit slow at times so bringing an ethernet cord or a wireless router would not be a bad idea.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: amazing. warm and pleasant most of the year. rains a lot in summer months, though, so make sure you have a raincoat and rain boots
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: There is always transportation available, if you're willing to pay for it. Cabs can be expensive but you usually get to split the cost. However, the street car is only $1.50. It just takes a really long time to get anywhere.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Well it's New Orleans, so they have the streetcar system. The line is very close to school, it's super cheap, and very easy to understand. They do run a bit slow, however. Aside from the streetcar there are taxis. The taxis here are generally unreliable and expensive.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: New Orleans is a great place to be, and there's always something to do.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Although NOLA does not have as an extensive public transit program as NY or other big cities, the cable cars and buses will get you where you need to go eventually. They are fun to ride and fairly reliable. Tulane also offers shuttles to places not the public routes.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: It's in New Orleans! There is no other city with this much culture, vibrance, and life. There is always something to do or go see, as long as you take advantage of the location and do not get stuck in the "tulane bubble."
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: The public transportation is really good, you can get most places in the city for a fairly small cost. The University provides a free shuttle system to big places (like malls) that are beyond the bus system. The biggest problem with transportation here is getting to and from the airport.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: There are a lot of computers available in the library, but internet speed is pretty slow. I suggest having your own computer because it ensures you have a computer when you need it.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Nowhere has a better local atmosphere than New Orleans.  In Louisiana, there is an average of one festival a day going on somewhere.  Many are in or around New Orleans.  The French Quarter is a guaranteed party every weekend.  It lights up during Halloween and Mardi Gras.  For those who like history, there are several buildings older than the country that they are in and there is the WWII museum to see as well.  Shopping is inconvenient, because almost all require some kind of shuttle ride to get there because there is little room in the city.  People are nice to students, especially those that depend on them for income.  We have the Saints and the hornets to provide entertainment.  No one cares about Tulane football, because we are awful.  New Orleans can be a dangrous place.  Be safe.  Stay in groups and don't go places where you can't see anyone around.  If you come here and have nothing to do, the you are doing New Orleans wrong.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: There are computer labs in almost every residence hall as well as in the library, and buildings that house a department (ex. business and architecture).  A spot is always open and laptops aren't unnecessary, but most people have laptops with them most of the time and it is much more convenient.  WIFI is in every building, but it is unreliable.  It generally works, but at least 10 minutes a day, people have trouble with the speed going down to levels that makes it unusable for that period of time.  The Ethernet doesn't work well, and the network settings make it almost impossible to set up many devices on it (printers, game consoles,...).
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Transportation is pretty great if you factor in both the school and public options. Tulane provides free shuttles that will take you to places most students want/need to go, like the local malls, grocery stores, and so forth. Also, they have shuttles that make rounds at night to make sure that people who want to go out are safe and you can call them for a pick-up. The streetcars in New Orleans are very inexpensive ($1.25/ride) and will take you to most of the other place you would want to go, like to the French Quarter and along Saint Charles or down Carrollton.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: During midterms and finals, you're likely to find the library and similar places very crowded. Almost everyone has their own laptop (I don't know a single person who doesn't) and common places people prefer to study fill up extremely fast around the middle and end of a semester. If you want to print something and don't have your own printer, you have a few options: printing at a library/cafe (costs money, but you're given plenty at the beginning of the semester on your ID card), or printing for free at a location like Hillel (limit on the number of pages you can print at one time).
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: I personally haven't found that I need a car on campus.  I've done perfectly fine without one, though it is helpful that some of my friends have their cars here.  It's more of a convenience than anything.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: New Orleans is an amazing city. There are boundless opportunities to go to awesome festivals, restaurants, and cool little shops. The hard part is finding people who want to do that, because, God forbid, it might interrupt some of their drinking time.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Very bipolar, but generally sunny and relatively warm. Always have an umbrella on hand!
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: New Orleans is the land of bipolar weather. Sometimes torrential downpours will start out of nowhere, and the humidity can be killer in August, and hurricanes happen. But, we can wear shorts well into December sometimes, and when the weather is nice, it's really really nice, and there is so much to do in the city and on campus on those days. So, a B it gets, simply for it's unpredictability.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: Campus life is by far the most unique thing about Tulane. New Orleans is a very unique city which is reflected by campus life. For instance we are the only university that allows the sell of alcohol at our sporting events and we even sell booze in the the student center
Campus.Author: College Senior

Campus.Review: It gets really, really, really hot sometimes but it's usually not unbearable, and you can't beat shorts until December.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: New Orleans is an amazingly colorful city with a million things to do. It is also unsafe to walk around by yourself.
Campus.Author: College Senior

Campus.Review: It is always so hot and humid here, its hard to want to walk to classes, but in the "winter" it gets better.  You almost never need a jacket.
Campus.Author: Recent Alumnus

Campus.Review: Hit or miss ‚Äì Tulane is an old school. Therefore there are buildings which are old. Some of the original buildings (Gibson, Dinwiddie, Norman Meyer, Richardson) are a little outdated and the classrooms feel like they could use some revamping. But some of the other buildings are spectacular. The LBC is modern, new, and feels like a hotel lobby. The law and business school buildings are incredible, and even some of the dorms (Wall!!) qualify as luxurious.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: It Works Well ‚Äì There's the street car, Safe Ride, Tulane weekend shuttles, airport shuttles, and other modes of transportation. Even some taxis roll through campus now and then.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: So Far So Good ‚Äì Yeah, it's very hot and very humid during the August/September months but it cools down like everywhere else afterwards. The intense amount of AC in the dorms and buildings offsets the extreme heat outside, so it's not that bad.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: New Orleans Student Life ‚Äì The social scene is unlike any other school. A lot of bars are 18 and up, so most students go out, rather than house parties. New Orleans is the greatest city in the country and an awesome place to be a student. Tulane is a highly respected institution where you can get a great education but still have lots of fun!
Campus.Author: College Senior

Campus.Review: Reily Center is a pretty good gym but could use more machines. The library is improved with more electrical plug-ins for laptops and the librarians are very helpful. Bars are close by and everyone sticks pretty close to campus when going out.
Campus.Author: College Senior

Campus.Review:
It's New Orleans ‚Äì New Orleans is a wonderful city if you're smart about how you live there. If you're out late at night, you need to be in groups and have reliable transportation, because it can be dangerous. Tulane is in Uptown, a nicer part of the city but there's still crime. 

The campus is close to Magazine Street, where there are many nice, small shops. The school is close to many great restaurants and is a relatively quick bus or streetcar ride away from the French Quarter, where there is always something to do. Music events and festivals are quite common. There is no city in America quite like New Orleans.

New Orleans shopping is very expensive, however, and many of the restaurants are quite pricey too.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: There's Always Something ‚Äì Tulane has a fairly new student union, called the LBC by students, that has several restaurants in its food court, as well as a sports bar in the basement that is very popular for late night snacking; the LBC also has many comfortable, quiet places to study and large ballrooms that are used for various meetings and club activities. There are two athletic centers, one that is available for use by all students and another that is currently being constructed that is intended to be used by student athletes. Both are very well-equipped. The student athletic center has plenty of machines and has space available for everything from basketball to swimming and boasts numerous fitness classes that students can take. McAlister auditorium holds movies that are free to attend on some weekends and on Fridays, there are events held on the quad (aptly named Fridays at the Quad) that provide free catered food, tee shirts, samples, as well as the opportunity to hear live music and get involved in various school groups.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: New Orleans ‚Äì It's in New Orleans. No matter what type of person you are or what you like to do on the weekend, you will be able to find a place to go and people who are like the same things as you.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review:
It's a Tight-Knit City. Be Ready to Walk ‚Äì New Orleans has everything available to you within fifteen minutes by living on campus at Tulane University. A streetcar ride from campus to the quarter is about fifteen minutes and $1.25. It runs all night long, although the pick-up intervals will be far and in-between.

I have walked to concert venues, restaurants, the quarter, and friends' houses while living on campus, and I have never had to walk too far.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: New Orleans is incredibly hot, no one can stress that enough. The first few months of the semester and the final weeks of May are tough to walk to classes in, but this also means that the winters are pretty mild. The city is very humid, so though the heat is painful, the winters can feel worse than they actually are. It gets to be in the 40s and 50s in the Winter, sometimes climbing up into the 70s! It's very inconsistent. Springs and Summers are rainy, so bring umbrellas and rainboots!
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Ridiculously Expensive, but the Tickets Hurt ‚Äì Parking on campus at Tulane is a necessary evil for students with cars. Since the city atmosphere brings violence and carjackings with it, it is crucial to park your car on campus where the campus police are responsible for protecting it. However, year-long parking passes cost $500, which will put a hurt on anyone's wallet.
