Since public transportation in New Orleans is so good, why not save yourself the hassle of parking and skip the car altogether?
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Many Diversions in a Great Neighborhood ‚Äì Tulane is fortunate to be situated in uptown New Orleans- the safest, richest and prettiest part of town. The campus blends gracefully into residential neighborhoods and local restaurants, which provide classy and safe diversions for students. There are plenty of coffeehouses, restaurants and clothing boutiques within easy walking distance of campus, so students are never bored. The St. Charles streetcar is only a fifteen-minute walk from the dormitories, making it very easy to get to the French Quarter and Downtown. Bets of all, the surrounding neighborhoods have a very positive attitude towards Tulane's presence in uptown NOLA.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: So you know you are going to have fun. The city has its own culture with Creole vivacity and the beautiful, French buildings in the French Quarter. The food is great and the people are wonderful!
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Horrible to Do ‚Äì You need permits for the few parking spaces. It is dangerous to park in some since you might get towed.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Always a Fest!! There is something to do every weekend in the city of New Orleans.  Pro sports, the Riverwalk, culture, music festivals and of course food, food, food!!! The awesome year round weather lends itself to New Orleans and the Tulane area being destinations for not only students and parents, but vacationers from all over the world.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review:
Insufficient Computer Maintenance ‚Äì - Lab computers not always working.
- Lack of maintenance.
Campus.Author: Recent Alumnus

Campus.Review: On-campus shuttles are free and they will take you to the mall, WalMart, Target, and the downtown campus.  In my experience the shuttles are hit or miss.  I've had ones on time and ones that were very late. Taxis are relatively cheap and the streetcar and the buses are very reasonable and very good ways to get around the city itself.  Have found no need for a car on campus and freshmen can't have one anyway.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: When It Rains, It Is a Disaster ‚Äì the NOLA weather is, for the most part, the best you can find in the country. But when the downpour comes, it will flood the street within 20 minutes. Be prepared to get wet shoes while walking to classes. Not fun at all! It happened five times during my freshman year.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: When it's not sunny and humid, it's often dreary and rainy in New Orleans. One day it could be absolutely beautiful and the next it could pour all day so the weather is often pretty random. Since New Orleans is below sea level, winters can get relatively cold because of the dampness in the air. However, you never have to worry about snowstorms or extreme cold, and it stays warm and pretty well until january.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: The quality of campus facilities differ because things were built/rebuilt at different times. The gym is average, and could use more machines. However the student center is pretty central to campus and has a lot to offer. Sometimes I wish there were more places to study besides the library or the LBC because places get crowded during certain points of the year.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Only in NOLA ‚Äì Attending Tulane allows for a college experience that is unlike any other all due to the fact that Tulane is located in New Orleans. There is always something fun to do on or off campus that can appeal to a diverse group of interests. Also, Audubon Park is right across the street from campus if you ever want a nature-y feel anda break from the whirlwind of NOLA.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Not So Great ‚Äì There aren't a lot of computer labs at Tulane. The library has decent access to computers, but that's about it. During midterms and finals it is difficult to secure a computer. I would recommend that you have your own personal computer. You receive $25 for printing each semester, and one page costs 10 cents (you have the option to print double sided). I have found that $25 per semester to be inadequate because I take classes that require more reading and writing. For some students, however, the $25 dollar amount is more than enough. If you run out, it is very easy to add more money to your account. The network is fairly reliable. Sometimes it stops working, but its usually back up withing a few hours. For a college campus, its about average.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: The campus is very attractive. Tulane has a lot of quads that can be used for pretty much anything, and they definitely add to campus aesthetics. Reily, Tulane's fitness center, is currently a little small, but is undergoing renovations to make it bigger and nicer. It has multiple basketball and racquetball courts, an indoor and outdoor pool, and two exercise classrooms which offer a wide selection of classes. The library is also a little small, but is likely to be renovated in the next few years. Particularly during finals and midterms, the library can feel cramped. It does, however, boast a large collection of books. The student center (the LBC) is a beautiful building that has dining and study space. It is entirely eco-friendly and houses many of the campus activities. Tulane has a large list of clubs and organizations, all of which can be seen on Tulane's website under "Student Life."
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: NEW ORLEANS ‚Äì Tulane is an amazing school that gives its students amazing opportunities. i am very involved in community service, and Tulane has gone above and beyond to ensure that I have good opportunities. Another thing that sets Tulane apart from the rest is location! Parents, don't be afraid that you are sending your children away to go play on bourbon street... WE DON'T GO THERE! Tulane is in the garden district which is in a fancy area of New Orleans so I always feel safe. There are many places besides bourbon street and the french quarter to go to like magazine street and audobon park. there are also amazing festivals such as craw fest and jazz fest. and of course MARDI GRAS which is loads of fun.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review:
It *Is* New Orleans ‚Äì I'm from up North, so the friendliness of New Orleans was a pleasant surprise when I moved down here. There is also a ton to do, for every interest, and students (with IDs) tend to get in cheaper to most museums and zoo-related establishments. The streetcar and bus lines make getting around easy, and Tulane offers a shuttle (or you can take a cab) to and from the airport.

Tulane is right next to Loyola, so there are some events and classes the two campuses share, which is awesome because you get to meet all sorts of people.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: No Need for a Car ‚Äì Going to school in a city is great because there are many transportation services.  Specifically, Tulane has access to the Street Car of New Orleans that is located right at the front of campus. It just costs $1.25 and can take you as far as the french quarter.  In order to get to campus most students fly.  The New Orleans airport is very easy and has many direct southwest flights.  Cab transportation picks you up at the airport and takes you directly to campus.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: the city is so unique and has so much food to eat and music to see. even if you dont like food and music there is a great art scene and tons of opportunities to make a positive impact in the community. i came from texas and fell in love with this city. read these current student blogs for more about new orleans  http://tutrutu.blogspot.com/
Campus.Author: College Senior

Campus.Review: There are about 5 spots that you have to pay $1000 for
Campus.Author: College Senior

Campus.Review: Big Easy ‚Äì There's literally so much to do in New Orleans. Whether you like the going out bar scene, music venues, good food, there's always something to do. Tulane also has started to offer events on weekends for those who don't like to go out.
Campus.Author: College Senior

Campus.Review: Non-Stop Entertainment ‚Äì New Orleans is an incredibly fun city to attend college in.  There are hundreds of bars and night life spots, wonderful restaurants, and easy transportation in the form of the streetcar.  Of course, Mardi Gras in the Spring semester is a huge deal too.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: New Orleans is bipolar to the extreme; one day it will be 75, the next 50. And it could be either January or September. Also, even when it gets cold, it still tends to feel humid, which sort of settles in your bones. It also rains a decent amount, so bring rain boots and keep an umbrella handy. HOWEVER, there are palm trees and you can wear shorts year-round, so it is worth it.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Roll Wave Bubble ‚Äì New Orleans is an amazing city and even though campus resides in a bubble, that bubble is porous.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Tulane a place where urban accessibility is easy for students. However, it is surrounded by large, old and beautiful houses, Loyola University and Audubon Park. Many delicious restaurants are available by street car or a walk. The campus feels safe, but close to off campus there are many robberies. Shopping is not near-by but Tulane provides a shuttle service to make them accessible. Cultural events include Mardi Gras, Crawfest, Oktoberfest, Friday at the Quad (with free local food and a free local band every Friday afternoon), all free Tulane sporting events, a great rec center, and a student attitude of "work hard, party harder." Also, Tulane students have a great reputation for community service.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Get the job done but they are generally old or basic. Nothing special.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Life Is a Party ‚Äì Going to school in New Orleans ensures that you you will never be bored on a Saturday night (or a monday, tuesday, wednesday, thursday, or friday night)! There is always some sort of festival or concert going on, and if there isn't one, the french quarter is always a party and there are 5 bars within walking distance of campus.  You can get the party scene by going to any school in New Orleans, but the special thing about Tulane is that it is a school where very motivated and intelligent students can go to work hard and play hard.  Most every one i have met at Tulane has big dreams of success and will work hard to make those dreams a reality, but when the weekend rolls around, they throw down as hard (if not harder) than students at other colleges.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: Great network and resources. Got internship Summer after freshman year and hope to continue a successful job search.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: I really loved the admission process with Tulane. I build a personal relationship with my admission counselor and it helped me get into Tulane.
Value.Author: College Senior

Value.Review: There are many opportunities for students to search for jobs within the career center.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: Tulane cares about their students. End of story.
Value.Author: College Junior

Value.Review: Most Offices have Tulane graduates as employees. The career center gets wonderful feedbacks from employers on the high performance of Tulane hires.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: A degree fro Tulane is invaluable, a notion I have experienced even before graduating.
Value.Author: College Junior

Value.Review: I don't have any personal experiences with the alumni network and I'm not sure I'd get much benefit from Tulane alumni in the future. Nonetheless, I still feel as though Tulane provides a quality education so the value of the degree will show once I begin studying at medical school. However, I would like to note that it took me several months of e-mailing and trying to visit 10+ professors before any of the laboratories at Tulane offered me an internship at both the downtown and uptown campus.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: I'm in the MAACT (Masters of Accounting) 5-year program, and it's been great networking with the Big 4 firms. I had many on-campus interviews that led to actual interviews with the firms and to internship offers.
Value.Author: College Junior

Value.Review: Opportunities for internships and work after college is great because of all the networking and connections.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: Tulane is the place to be
Value.Author: College Junior

Value.Review: I believe Tulane's community outreach requirement for graduation helps students obtain experience to add to their futures when seeking jobs and internships.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: I haven't found access to the resources
Value.Author: College Junior

Value.Review: Tulane is the best school in state and it's definitely very well known. I have never met anyone who wouldn't have at least heard about it and Tulane's alumni network is truly impressive. It's also really easy to get help with internships or jobs and academic/career advisors are always there for you. If you need to schedule an appointment to get some advice, the wait time is almost never longer than a day or two and you're most likely to see your advisors at least a few times each semester. There's also a ton of internship and job fairs happening all the time.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: Tulane, as a research institute, does a great job providing job and research opportunities for everyone. And since all professors do some sort of research, almost all departments are looking for student help.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: There are so many opportunities to meet and connect with the alumni. Along with a large variety of internship and job opportunities, so many professors do research, providing more than an ample amount of opportunities to get involved in your specific discipline.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: Most people don't realize how much of a party school Tulane is and therefore most people who aren't directly affiliated just see it as a good academic university.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: The career center offers various of career services and informs students with updating career opportunities frequently.
Value.Author: College Senior

Value.Review: Tulane has taught me many philosophical things, but very little of that can I use applying for a professional job anywhere outside or inside of the state
Value.Author: College Junior

Value.Review: I've had Wall Street executives tell me, "A Tulane degree does not go unnoticed."
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: There is a strong alumni network, and many professors are very willing to help as well. Many graduates go on to top graduate schools and work in major cities.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: Tulane is a respected school. You're fine.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: The name Tulane means a lot locally and nationally that graduating from the college gives you an advantage in the job competition scene.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: Tulane is a great school academically with a wonderful alumni network. We are not an Ivy League, but I would say that a degree from Tulane definitely competes with a degree from most Ivies, and it is up to the individual to distinguish him or herself; there are many opportunities for this at Tulane and in the surrounding areas.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: I've heard that Tulane gives out the most financial aid/merit scholarships in the nation. This definitely seems to be true. So many people have scholarships and financial aid. Tulane definitely does an amazing job with aid.
Value.Author: Recent Alumnus

Value.Review: They are the a few schools that provide scholarships to international students.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: I got a great merit scholarship.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: The Business school has a great network for the students. Freemanlink shows jobs and internships available in many different areas of the world and country.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: I am currently trying to get financial aid for the summer. It is not bad, you just have to keep checking up on it.
Value.Author: College Junior

Value.Review: I have to apply for a lot of scholarships to keep paying for school. I think tuition and food is way overpriced. This is an amazing school, no doubt, but it could be just as good for less. There are so many activities on campus that aren't that necessary, clubs have a lot of money to spend. I would rather pay directly for all the additional benefits.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: Tulane's pretty generous with merit as they should be with the price of our tuition. Still, the awards could be better.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: Scholarships are generous & plenty.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: We have career fairs, internship fairs, etc. all the time.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: Extremely generous with merit scholarships
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: It all went pretty easily and was handled efficiently, i've had zero problems and havent heard of other having any problems either
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: I was a transfer student. I came to visit the campus to see if I wanted to transfer. After meeting with the Dean of Admission, he offered me a scholarship on the spot. It was awesome!
Value.Author: College Junior

Value.Review: It is SO easy to find internships and jobs on campus. There are always job/internship fairs going on, and getting an internship is part of a degree requirement. There are also several 1 credit courses available to prepare you for finding an internship or job. I have found these courses to be extremely helpful.
Value.Author: College Junior

Value.Review: Tulane gives out tons of merit-based scholarship, more than most schools of the same ranking. I didn't apply for financial aid, but did receive a good amount of scholarship
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: They have recently updated the student portal website and it is much more user friendly now! Don't be afraid to e-mail your financial aid counselor with questions.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: Early Action helps a lot in scholarship.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: Tulane has a great reputation and employers are always looking to recruit from us, whether it's local, national, or global; there are always opportunities
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: Tulane has job and career fairs all the time and gives our resumes to potential employers, so that's nice. There's a really wide alumni network and they seem to be pretty spirited about hiring Tulane grads. The career center is pretty helpful about interview skills and writing a resume.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: I have full tuition which is super great considering the cost.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: Until a few days ago, I thought this would be my last year due to a lack of appropriate need-based aid. Tulane cut everything after my brother left school (Harvard, for which he only paid $7000 a semester). I am able to stay only after months of fighting with the financial aid office, and I am just getting by on what I have received.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: The school is very open to helping students find and apply for scholarships. As well as being able to suggest and add new scholarships that the student was unaware that they were eligible for.
Value.Author: College Senior

Value.Review: They give out about 4 full scholarships but also give out generous partial scholarships apparently.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: Many students are on scholarship in correlation with their GPA.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: tulane has a large endowment and therefore a lot of scholarship money to offer, however it will not just appear in your lap. you need to be proactive to receive more if you need it
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: The financial aid office has pretty rude employees. Make sure you to get in contact with your financial aid adviser, and ask questions on how to receive more aid. They are usually really helpful.
Value.Author: College Junior

Value.Review: I typically receive all the financial aid that I need with ease of my financial advisor, who is very helpful and efficient.
Value.Author: College Senior

Value.Review: The financial aid made the school a lot more affordable and makes up for the high tuition rate. Most people I know are on some sort of financial aid and the higher your high school grades, the better your financial aid will be.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: I had no problems with my financial aid but I know several people who have especially people who were awarded academic scholarships and deferred for a gap year and didn't get them back . They also won't allow you to get any money in cash/check if you have extra and force you to keep the balance in your accounts receivable.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: It's rather challenging if you receive no merit aid but are requesting it.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: Tulane is VERY generous with scholarship money and have a few full tuition ones. They're even more generous if you're a Louisiana resident.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: Got a great scholarship. Financial aid had no issues.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: I have a single mother who has four kids to support and even with the various loans I have she is struggling to pay for my college
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: I have never had any issues.
Value.Author: College Junior

Value.Review: Great scholarships are given but it is easy not to qualify
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: Tulane offers great scholarships. I only know a few people who did not receive one of $10,000 or more. However, i have had friends that have had awful experiences with financial aid. You really need to have some money to attend this school.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: I suggest giving in your family's taxes for that year before applying and then downloading most of the information through the IRS site.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: I dont have any scholarship opportunities that are available in other colleges for students majoring in Masters in Public Health
Value.Author: College Junior

Value.Review: Tulane gives a ton of academic scholarships out. Many people you talk to are on some kind of scholarship or grant.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: I was awarded financial aid but still struggle with loans.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: I applied for the Dean's Honors scholarship and got it. Tulane has been extremely on top of updating my financial aid and making sure it is taken care of.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: Freshman and sophomore year financial aid was somewhat helpful, but the older I have gotten the less helpful they have been. They also reduced the amount of my aid, and claimed it was because I did not turn my forms in in time.
Value.Author: College Senior

Value.Review: They're not extremely generous with financial aid but a lot of people ended up with huge scholarships without even looking for one, so although Tulane is a very expensive school to attend, with the scholarships it ends up being the cheapest option for a lot of people.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: As a student from a low-income family, I received the maximum amount the school gives for financial aid. The school does not give full rides, and I was stuck with a lot of loans and having to come up with an average of $2000 out of pocket per semester. However, other wealthier students primarily come to Tulane because they were given more financial aid than other schools offered. So Tulane financial aid caters to middle-upper class students.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: Tulane is great about giving merit based scholarships to students. Just based upon my application I was offered a scholarship that covered about half of the tuition and some for living costs (going to the dorms of course). Because Tulane is an expensive university I would suggest looking elsewhere to find additional money such as external scholarships or loans. Overall I would say Tulane is excellent about it's financial aid, one of the highlights of the school.
Value.Author: Recent Alumnus

Value.Review: I was a grad student so all it included was loan apps, you have to call multiple times as with all schools to get info and directions though, be protective
Value.Author: College Senior

Value.Review: Tulane is know for its amount of money that it gives to it's students. It is fantastic at giving money to those in need.
Value.Author: Recent Alumnus

Value.Review: It was a hassle but I did receive the financial aid that I needed to help pay my tuition.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review:
More, More, More Please ‚Äì I am currently a Tulane student with a decent scholarship, but as for receiving enough funds  - it's slim pickings for a kids with ambition and drive. Although there is the full-ride Dean's Honors Scholarship, there is not much else for students looking to remain at the school for all four years. Tulane increased its tuition costs this past year, and although the cost is usually downgraded by a student loan or scholarship, the years pile up, and in the past the financial aid office has not been available for much help. 

The financial aid office was revamped this past year to offer more beneficial services though, so I suppose time will tell. Until then - I will be on the look-out for outside scholarships that can at least cover the cost of books.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: Automatic Consideration ‚Äì And as long as you maintain a 2.7, you keep it. They're very generous to get the brightest minds to attend.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: Tulane is known to be pretty generous with giving out scholarship money for merit and need based, however I have met some people (who seem extremely deserving) who mentioned that they received very little money. However, most people say they chose to attend Tulane because of the large amount of scholarship money they were awarded.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: Could Have Been Worse ‚Äì Tulane gives a lot of financial aid to its students. In fact, most students who attend have a Tulane scholarship. The workers at the Financial Aid Office are very friendly and helpful. When I had questions or problems, I just walked into the office and was helped right away. There are, of course, tons of forms you have to fill out (FAFSA, CSS, copies of W2s, non-filer forms, etc), but that would be the same at any school. I suggest that you befriend your financial aid adviser and stay on top of deadlines.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: Tulane University is known for handing out large amounts of financial aid, both need-based and merit-based.  Almost all of my friends have some sort of scholarship.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: Used to Be Great, Dunno About That Anymore ‚Äì They used to give almost everyone a scholarship when I was admitted, but I hear they are getting more stingy as more and more people are applying to Tulane. Personally, I got the Dean's Honor Scholarship which covers 100% tuition. They give that out to 100 applicants a year. I still end up paying around $5000 a year in various fees and books, but it's nice to know I won't have any loans. Most of my friends got the presidential scholarship which I think covers around $20000 a year.
Value.Author: College Senior

Value.Review: The school provides qualified students with a great deal of merit aid, as well as financial need based aid
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: Very Easy ‚Äì You are atutomatically entered to recieve academic finanical aid upon applying to Tulane, and if you recieve scholarship it is automatically awarded.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review:
I attended Tulane on a merit-based scholarship for which I was automatically considered and did not have to apply for.  The scholarship covered nearly half of my tuition and made it possible for me to attend solely with assistance from my parents.  I was very fortunate to not have to rely on outside financial aid, so I'm afraid I won't be able to give much advice on this topic.
I lived in the honors dorm freshman year, and the majority of its residents were also receiving merit-based scholarships - Tulane seemed to be very generous in awarding them to incoming freshman.
Value.Author: Recent Alumnus

Value.Review: Tedious but Worth It ‚Äì The time it takes to apply for, reapply for, and gather and submit every form needed is very time consuming and can be costly, but the payout is normally very high. Unfortunately, with tuition rising each year, the school will need to start giving out more scholarships and grants to students in need.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: Merit Money ‚Äì They give you a generous academic scholarship if you deserve it. In fact, the scholarship is what brought in the majority of the honors students in the freshman class, who were also accepted to schools like WashU, Harvard, Vanderbilt, etc. because those schools aren't nearly as generous.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Off campus is amazing. There is no place like New Orleans food. However, on campus is very average.With only one dining hall, it gets old. But the dining hall is not bad by any means.
Food.Author: Recent Alumnus

Food.Review: You cannot beat New Orleans food. There are so many options. I didn't even like seafood before getting here, and now I love it.
Food.Author: Recent Alumnus

Food.Review: Lots of choices, but a little far
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Sometimes Bruff is so gross, but sometimes it gives you some surprise.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: NOLA food is great! I'm just like poor.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Bruff is kind of gross and unhealthy. At least it's convienient?
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: The meal plan is overpriced. However, if you choose the option with more WaveBucks, you can just eat at the LBC and Le Gourmet which are both good options!
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: We have many fast food restaurants nearby and we also have City Diner that is open at night. this makes getting food during the night easy.
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: The food in every dining place on campus is good.
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: I will say that people are not happy when you dine off campus. It is a hassle and the waitress at Jazmine Cafe will be very mad. You should always tip your waitresses.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Its the best of any college I've been to. Unfortunately, everything is overpriced.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Average food. Bruff tries to respond to student feedback and is improving. Boot pizza is always the answer though.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: New Orleans is great with food. Many tasty places that are affordable for students. Also, there is a good number of coffee shops off-campus.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: LBC is great. PJ's & Starbucks are delightful.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Cant live in New Orleans without loving the food
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: The premade food is not great- often saturated in oil. But, if you get a little creative with making your food, Bruff can be great
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: Its not the best. At least there is always cereal or sandwiches
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: I looooove Bruff! Most people complain about it, but I regularly eat fresh fruit with a dairy product and nuts as well as a plate of veggies and vegan grains, and soup. Loyola also has a dining hall that Tulane students can eat at, but its options are severely limited in comparison to Bruff and I often find trouble finding health options that aren't just salad. The LBC also has a food court.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: New Orleans dining couldn't be better.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: If you want walking distance there are options (felipe's, dough bowl, Dat Dog), if you want delivery there is good pizza and stuff, and if you actually want to go outside of the Tulane zone for a meal then you're in the best city in the world for it.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: There is a variety of options, however there are not that many healthy options sometime.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: I love the food here.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: the best food in the whole world literally.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Bruff isn't the best, although is is super convenient. The LBC has some good places, but not all of it is the healthiest. As a freshman, get the meal plan with the maximum number of wave bucks. You'll get sick of Bruff with the unlimited plan and not have enough wave bucks for when you don't want to eat there.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Everything is kind of pricey, but it is NOLA...
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: It's New Orleans, of course it's good.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: you can't go wrong with food in New Orleans. If you get sick of bruff, the LBC, or loyola, it's very easy to walk, take the streetcar, bike, or cab it to any delicious off campus restaurant
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: There are a lot of nice local spots around campus and a fair amount of popular chain restaurants. It cam be difficult to get to a lot of these restaurants because the street car is pretty slow and unreliable.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: It's New Orleans. There's a little bit of everything. Included with meal plans are NOLA bucks you can use at a selection of off campus restaurants and there are sometimes discounts or free appetizers if you wear Tulane gear. The crepe place is my entire life.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: The food is good, but it's a long walk to get anywhere. Generally, I'd rather not walk too far off-campus at night unless I need to.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: I have a lot of food allergies and the chefs are very accommodating.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Bruff (the cafeteria) sucks. The food is always gross and the salad bar is always wilted and just nasty. The pasta bar is pretty good though. Loyola's cafeteria is 100x better even though both cafeterias hire the same company (Sodexo). Wavebucks can be used in the food court, which I do a lot and a lot of close by resteraunts take Nolabucks.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Campus dining is a hit or a miss, depending on the day. The kitchen prepares fantastic local cuisine some night, and very bland food the next.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: New Orleans serves amazing and unique food.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: a ton of different options that you can hardly even try all of the first year. it takes a lot of time and experimentation to even get to a fraction of the great eateries that uptown, as well as downtown, new orleans has to offer. top notch.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: People complain a lot about bruff but you get pretty used to it and its not that bad.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Bruff Dining Hall is good during the first month of every semester and then it's awful. Learning how to cook simple meals for yourself in the dorm kitchens will help you avoid bruff at least a couple of meals a week.
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: Bruff gets old so it's nice to have the LBC to get food at to add variety.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Uptown New Orleans has a large number of restaurants to choose from and downtown is just a streetcar ride away.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Most places surrounding campus is reasonable in cost. Not very many  places give student discounts that I know of.
Food.Author: College Senior

Food.Review: The dining hall kinda sucks. It mostly sucks that there's only one and sometimes it's really crowded and they run out of stuff. It just gets old eating the same thing every day so my friends and I avoid going there. Sophomore year I went to Bruff probably once every few weeks if even that. The LBC food court is okay but if you eat there every day you get sick of eating the same thing over and over. Wavebucks are fun though because they feel like Monopoly money. Le gourmet is really good for an on campus option. I pretty much ate off campus for most meals sophomore year.
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: New Orleans offers tons of off campus dining options of all cuisines and prices. There's something for everyone and the options never get old.
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: Bruff is blah the LBC is good.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: As expected of most colleges, the food isn't that great, which is ironic considering Tulane is located in the middle of one of the world's best cities for food! Tough it out until Junior year when you can move off campus and cook for yourself.
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: Its exactly what you would expect from college dining. Bruff isn't terrible and it isn't the best
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Dat-Dog is about a mile, maybe a mile and a half away from campus on Freret. It's sooo good! It's hot dogs, but they're not your typical kind of hot dogs. You can get a vegan dog, or a kosher one. How about trying a crawfish dog, or maybe some alligator. Of course, beef is also an option. Though they're a little on the more pricey end, about $7 a hot dog, they're definitely worth it. They're a  hit at school! But they only take cash, so that's a little inconvenient when you forget. And their fries are delicious!
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Off campus dining is amazing, because it's New Orleans and there are an endless supply of restaurants to choose from which makes up for the mostly horrible/expensive food on campus.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: If you have a car or time to walk, I've found a lot of amazing restaurants.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: It's New Orleans. Food here is amazing (not alot of Tex Mex or chinese though). Places near campus are a little limited but are really good.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: You have to get creative after a while.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: New Orleans has some of the best food in the country! And Uptown is nice because it's not just all fast food.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Pretty good in terms of the number of options available, but lacking in the convenience of getting to those places (taking streetcar, walking, etc.)
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: It's New Orleans; the food is the best in the world.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: I love most of the food here
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Again - New Orleans! Hell-OOOO!! We have everything here. Seriously, name a type of food, and there's a restaurant minutes from campus. Downtown, check out Antoine's and The Gumbo Shop for great NOLA food. Uptown, hit up Felipe's! Plus, we have The NOLA Food Delivery Service - AKA whatever, whenever hand delivered!
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: It's New Orleans. There is always somewhere new and exciting to eat!
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: New Olreans has amazing food just get off campus whenever you can to try it out. there are great places around campus and downtown if you take the trolley for $1.25 most places are little on the pricier side because its great food. lots of places deliver to your dorm
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Could be more options for places to eat and better quality from the dining hall.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: As someone who puts a great amount of effort into making good food, having little access to a kitchen (one that is horribly stocked and despairingly messy) and getting the majority of my meals from a dining hall has been a struggle. I visit the Loyola University dining hall next door much more frequently than I do Tulane's.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: New Orleans cuisine is original and although the restaurants surrounding campus aren't limited to the creole style, it is one of the things that make eating out so enjoyable.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: New Orleans has some of the best food in the world. It's great to be able to experience all that the city has to offer.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: My campus is right in the middle of New Orleans with easy access to downtown, uptown, and the French Quarters so the off-campus dining does not only have a huge variety of food but it is also good quality and easily accessible.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Most students utilize Bruff to satisfy their hunger; it is fairly good for a college cafeteria. Students also have many other options.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: The main dining hall started off great, but it got very redundant and boring. There are great options off campus but other than that there aren't many good options on campus.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: New Orleans has some of the greatest food and restaurants in the country. There are close strips of restaurants on Maple, Oak and Freret.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Dining options are average. Normal college cafeteria food. There are always other options such as the food court in the LBC or the city diner.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Off campus dining is excellent, I wish it was a little bit more accessible though.  It's kind of spread out all over the place.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Mediocre.  Expensive for on campus dining.  I prefer to eat elsewhere.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Dining is very accessible and there are a variety of options both in the cafeteria and food court. The school convenient store has frozen meal and snack options as well. It's all average but convenient.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Bruff has good days and bad days. When it's good it's really good but sometimes you'll go and actually not be able to find any edible-looking food. Loyola's dining hall is generally better, but it has weird hours and isn't open in the middle of the day. If you're nice to the Bruff workers, they'll be nice to you. They will not be nice to you if you're rude or if they catch you trying to steal food.
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: Bruff dining hall gets old, but it's useful that Loyola's campus dining is also available for Tulane students. There are also a lot of great off campus options that are close to campus.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: In New Orleans there are a plethora of good restaurants that are affordable and diverse and many of them are surrounding the campus.
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: It's okay. Yeah, there are days when everything looks repulsive, and the workers can be meanies, but there are also days when all the food is delicious and the nice lady in the sandwich line calls you Honey. I suggest only getting the 3 meals a day plan.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Tulane's dining hall is not only unhealthy in terms of nutrition, it is also very poor in terms of hygeine/cleanliness. During your stay on campus, all meal plans cost the same (which is a good thing!) but in order to really stay healthy you often find yourself searching off-campus for food. Food off-campus (some near campus) is amazing, and so is the dining hall of the school NEXT DOOR that is covered under your meal plan.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: There is only one cafeteria on campus, and its not awful but definitely has room more improvement. The student center has a few additional options, so eating on campus can get boring after a while. Off campus has tons of options, but most of them you need a car to get to.
Food.Author: College Senior

Food.Review: While I was at Tulane, Bruff was a pretty awful place to eat, in terms of quality of food, but you could do worse I suppose. The LBC had more options of course, but New Orleans has amazing food. If you want to have good eats, good variety (of food and of prices), explore the city. Perhaps as a freshmen you'll eat mostly on campus, but if you have some extra cash go out and explore the restaurant scene in NOLA.
Food.Author: Recent Alumnus

Food.Review: The cafeteria at Tulane is notoriously awful. The utensils are dirty and the food is weird. The only time we get legit meals are for parents weekends like homecoming and orientation. I primarily eat at the food court which has a wide selection of choices. However, after 4 years you get tired of eating the same foods. Luckily, our meal plans are accepted at Loyola University next door and there are some restaurants around campus so we can switch it up.
Food.Author: College Senior

Food.Review: Bruff isn't a 5-star restaurant, but the hours are pretty decent (closes at 10pm on weekdays). The LBC food court is good too, but the hours are very inconvenient if you want a later meal.  City Diner is open 24hr, so if you want something late-night on campus, that's the place to go.  If you are looking for a good meal, take the time to go off campus and explore the city and the awesome restaurants around town.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: You are in New Orleans!!
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Bruff is always available and a viable option, but it closes really early.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: New Orleans is famous for it's food, and thousands of restaurants of literally every cuisine are accessible to Tulane students.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Although dining has improved in recent years and there are more options, Bruff still has very mediocre food. You can eat there and be fine for the year, but don't have high expectations. Get the dining plan with more Wavebucks!
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: They're literally everywhere. Just off the top of my head, Dough Bowl, Crepe place, Dat dog, Company burger, Felipe's, Naked pizza and Frostop. All are within a few blocks off campus. If you venture even further off there's fast food, sushi, BBQ, seafood, beignets and really anything you could ever want. New Orleans is food heaven. You might gain a Tulane 200.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Campus dining is relatively poor in the scheme of New Orleans. The main dining facility, Bruff, (although I have not been there in 2 years) has been characteristically poor with limited options. There are other dining facilities on campus that are available to students and are of much better quality, however they are highly inflated and are therefore very pricey. The best way to use your meal plan is to get WaveBucks which is money that you can utilize at a variety of off campus dining locations.
Food.Author: College Senior

Food.Review: Off-campus dining is readily available since Tulane is conveniently located in Uptown New Orleans. By either walking, taking the bus, or simply traveling by streetcar for only $1.25 you can get to just about anywhere in the city. Most dining options in the uptown area collaborate with the University and offer some sort of student discount or coupons specifically for students. There is even a growing list of dining options nearby campus that are now accepting money on your student ID included in your meal plan to pay for your meals. New Orleans is a city of great cultural diversity and therefore great diversity in variety of dining. Almost any type of food desired can be found within reasonable distance of campus. But a word of caution, if you crave any sort of Asian cuisine on Mondays, it would be best to go before 3pm or you may not be able to curb your craving until Tuesday.
Food.Author: College Senior

Food.Review: Bruff isn't that bad ‚Äì Tulane only has one cafeteria- Bruff. The food can be a little scary sometimes but it's really not that bad. They always have cereal, waffles, soda, pizza, salad bar, sandwich bar, and burgers among having nightly specials. The LBC has a bunch of chain restaurants that our meal plans work with so when Bruff gets old we can go there. There's also the option to go to the Orleans Room at Loyola University right next door (we call it luff). Their food is much much better.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Fat Hen ‚Äì Fat hen Barbeque is awesome!!!! It is also close to campus.
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: No Questions There. Tulane is located in New Orleans! Come on people there's no question that off-campus dining at Tulane are some of the best restaurants in the country and even the world! NOLA is your playground at Tulane, so take advantage of everything is has to offer! It's such a diverse and worldly city so there's just about every type of cuisine: Cajun, French, Italian, Mediterranean, African, Mexican, Latin American, etc. The possibilities are endless!
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: A Lot of Options ‚Äì There are plenty of on-campus options at Tulane, the most common being the main dining hall Bruff. Bruff does tend to have the same foods but the ways in which you can prepare different meals are limitless. In the LBC, there are a bunch of options like Panda Express or Quiznos and there is even an on-campus health foods grocery store. And to top it off, Tulane students have access to the dining options next door at Loyola University New Orleans!
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Can Get Very Tiring ‚Äì Bruff is the only traditional dining hall on campus. Because of this, it is very easy to get tired of the food that is available. While there are other options, they require the use of wavebucks (250 of which are given with the meal plan) or money out of your pocket, which means that many students eat the majority of their meals in Bruff. The other option is to go to Loyola's campus and eat in their dining hall (called the OR but referred to by Tulane students as 'Luff'). This does provide some better choices and a change of atmosphere that keeps things from getting too stale. If you are willing to spend the money, there is a lot of great food to be had on and around campus, however - a favorite is late night crepes.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review:
It's Getting Better ‚Äì Just this past year, Sodexo and Tulane have worked out many kinks in the food dining system. This past spring semester, Tulane had installed a new bakery with freshly baked treats and even amped up the healthier options. What is still unfortunate is that for vegans and vegetarians, the options remain locked in a freezer behind the "my kitchen" line, which offers a varying meal every day. 

Although the vegans and vegetarians do not have as many options, the variety that Tulane is trying to bring to its main dining hall, Bruff Commons, is increasing every semester.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Decent, Local Restaurants ‚Äì There are not a lot of restaurants to choose from. However, some of them are really great for the taste and the price such as Felipe's, Little Tokyo, and Camellia Grill (standard American burger joint). These are within walking distance and offer some variety in flavor. Other restaurants are so-so. The food is basic and decent but not really worth the price. In my opinion, Superior Grill (tex-mex) is extremely overrated. (Go to Felipe's instead.) By the way, there's also a drive-thru daquiri place you can walk to. You'll learn that that's how things go in New Orleans.
Food.Author: Recent Alumnus

Food.Review: Excellent Food in New Orleans ‚Äì There's a reason New Orleans has such a good reputation when it comes to food. There are a lot of great restaurants near campus in uptown. Magazine St., a short walk or streetcar ride away, has restaurants of every price range and cuisines. St. Charles Avenue has several restaurants in the Garden District if Tulane students take the streetcar down. There's also a crepe stand steps away from campus on Broadway, with delicious, cheap, fast crepes. It's a popular spot for students. Also, you can't miss the restaurants in the Warehouse District or the French Quarter!
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Bruff Ryders ‚Äì Everyone hates on bruff, I do too at times. It's on average kind of crappy but occasionally they step up and make some really good Cajun dish or soul food.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: It's New Orleans ‚Äì New Orleans has some of the best food in the country! It has its own unique foods like Jambalaya, Po Boys, Gumbo, and Beignets. You are never going to have food like this anywhere else
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Awesome Choices ‚Äì New Orleans is the perfect place for any food lover, and there are a lot of great places to check out around campus. The Dough Bowl, which is right across from the west side of campus, has amazing pizza which I would recommend to anyone. Magazine Street, which is about ten blocks off of St Charles, also has a lot of good eateries. Ignatius Eatery is a great place for cajun/creole food without  having to go all the way to the quarter.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Bruff is Tulane's dining hall, located right above the mail room and MacMart. There really is something for everyone here, from red beans and rice and fried chicken to pizza and the salad bar. Bruff isn't too bad (especially if you are like me and had parents that were horrible cooks), but in the event you get bored, you can head on over to Luff, which is on Loyola's campus, right next door. Luff has slightly better food quality, and not only does your Tulane meal plan work there, also, but you get to meet Loyola students. Just in case neither Luff nor Bruff are appealing, we also have McAlister Market (your Wavebucks work here, and are also part of your meal plan), where you can buy frozen dinners, Ramen, and the fixings for PB&J and the LBC, which has everything from fresh bagels to a Panda Express (your wavebucks work here, too). If none of that works for you, hey, YOU'RE IN NEW ORLEANS. Conveniently located near campus are the Camilla Grill, as well as any number of Italian, French, and Sandwich shops, and we're a short trolly ride from the French Quarter, for authentic gumbo.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Incredible Cajun Food ‚Äì New Orleans is world-renowned for its amazing, unique cuisine. I must admit, I do not like everything the city has to offer, since I am a very picky eater. Nevertheless, the originality and high quality and amazing taste of New Orleans cuisine is unmatched by any other city in the country, perhaps the world.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Solid, but Can Get Old Quickly ‚Äì The places around campus are fine. The dining hall has a little variety, but I'm a picky eater, so I'm able to deal with it. I hear a lot of kids complain about it, but I realize that it's not that great at other colleges anyway, so in comparison Tulane dining is pretty good.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Go Off Campus ‚Äì Tulane has only one dining hall (Bruff Commons) but a bunch of other places to eat around campus. The food at Bruff is nothing special and pretty much just like any other college campus dining hall. The meal options do get a little repetitive but the food is still decent. There are 2 PJs Coffee Houses on campus, and the RAT in the student center (open till 4am) has the best fast food around (with some healthy options of course). The LBC Center for University Life also hosts a variety of dining options in its food court. Students also frequently utilize the plethora of off campus restaurants that have some of the best food in the country.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Options in the LBC are limited. I'd love to see more options and better quality food there.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Food in New Orleans ‚Äì The food in New Orleans is incomparable to others. Tulane is aware of this so has "NOLAbucks" a meal plan students can use outside campus to get a good meal. The menu at the dining hall, Bruff, is very similar but good. The make your own omelet each morning is always a very popular stand
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Bruff if the dining hall and it is okay. its not that great but there are some good options. theres always a new thing at the chefs corner and that is usually pretty decent. the hot food they make is pretty bad but the other options are good if you mix it up. the lbc is good there are alot of really good options where you can use your wave bucks. le gourmet is also really good but expensive and uses alot of wave bucks. the crepe place is awesome and boot pizza late at night is great. off campus dining is amazing new orleans has so many ridiculously good places to eat
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: You Have Got to Be Kidding Me. TULANE IS IN NEW ORLEANS! This place is home to some of the greatest restaurants in the world. You can find something great tasting to eat at any point on the spectrum: from dirt cheap to expensive, from all kinds of different cuisines. Finding the really good places are half the fun!
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: On campus dining isn't really the best around. Bruff (the cafeteria) is not very good, and the workers are typically very rude to the students. The student union (LBC) has a few different little restaurants, but it is very expensive and gets mundane very quickly. Staff is pretty rude there too. We can use our student money at Loyola's campus which is kind of nice. Also Le Gourmet at Tulane and La Divinera at Loyola are both really good, but kind of pricey.
Food.Author: College Senior

Food.Review: New Orleans Food Is Awesome!! You can't beat the food in New Orleans - everywhere you go is delicious.  One of my favorite things to do is discover new restaurants and new foods.  Around campus there are a bunch of great restaurants, and if you go downtown you can find excellent local New Orleans and Cajun food!
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Lack of Option ‚Äì The Tulane Dining hall can get repetitive, and its hard to eat if you have special dietary needs such as vegetarian or gluten-free.  Additionally, it's hard to even find clean plates!  The options in the student union are a bit better, but you get bored of eating there.  Wavebucks are nice because you can use them all around campus and you can even use your meal swipes at the dining hall at Loyola next door, which offers much better food!
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: The food court is great.  There is tons of variety including Quizno's, Einstein Bagels, Baja Fresh, Panda Express, Byblos Greek, a salad bar, a sushi counter, and a smoothie bar.  If that's not good, you can use your meal plan dollars at the Tulane dining hall, the Loyola dining hall next door, and various places off campus and around Uptown New Orleans.
Food.Author: College Senior

Food.Review: We have The Boot, it isin't too far away, no student discounts, and they just sell pizza.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: There are so many GREAT restaurants in New Orleans, and most of them you will find nowhere else. There are many reasonably priced and delicious options around campus and some of them can even be included in meal plans. There are even more options on nearby Magazine Street that you can easily walk to. There are even more options in the Quarter. You can easily take the streetcar from the front of campus to downtown for only a $1.25. Be sure to go to Cafe Du Monde, its super cheap and a New Orleans institution with FANTASTIC beignets.
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: Food on Campus Is Terrible ‚Äì The dining hall is terrible food. The workers are not treated fairly and the meal plan is expensive and not worth it.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Dining Hall ‚Äì The food is a lot better than other dining halls that I have been to. They try to switch up the menu so it doesn't get to repetitive.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Local and American Food ‚Äì Almost every restaurant around campus is affordable and easy to get to. There is a very large variety of places. Camelia Grill, Creole Creamery, and Jacque-Imo's are must check out restaurants. They bring in a local flair to every experience.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: The french quarter is just a streetcar ride away! New Orleans has the best food in the world.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: I don't eat beef or pork which makes things kind of difficult, because most of the good looking pre-prepared meals contain one of the two. the food doesn't always seem very fresh, and I'm certain that most of it isn't organic. That being said, I don't go hungry. There are salad options and often a few vegetarian meal options. The dining hall is ugly and crowded, there are two tvs which play music videos nonstop and blast music making it hard to focus on the people your eating with. There is food at the lbc (baja fresh, Mediterranean togo, yummy bagels, panda express, sushi, quiznos, smoothies and frozen yogurt). You quickly run out of money to spend at lbc :)
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: There are major varieties of off-campus dining within the vicinity of the campus. If not walking distance, public transportation using streetcars along historic routes and the eco-friendly buses that are also available. There is the typical junk food [McDonald's, Burger King, Wendy's] and local restaurants [burger and hamburger joints, Mexican restaurants, pizza joints] and your fine dining restaurants are available too. Downtown is about 20 - 30 minutes using public transportation [under 15 minutes when not during rush hour].
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: Bruff commons needs to be revamped. the food isn't bad, but the hall itself is a little disappointing. This year, the staff went on strike due to poor pay and lack of benefits. Everyone on staff is so kind, many students supported the strike. The LBC is the student center and filled with food that's just great, quick, and easy. The RAT is under the LBC and is cheap food at late night.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review:
There are a lot of restaurants near campus, mostly Asian cuisine or moderately expensive, questionably good stuff, and none that I know of give student discounts. However, this year, they're including some local places in the meal plan (Camellia Grill is one of the big ones; it's open until something like 3am and serves ridiculously good food for a ridiculously good price, but to get to it you have to walk down Maple street, which is NOT safe at night, or go really out of your way down St Charles). Hana is another good restaurant, a japanese sushi place near Camellia Grill that is almost ridiculously cheap, considering all meals (except the noodles) come with some of the best salad you've ever had and soup, but watch out! They charge for refills on all drinks except water, which kind of sucks.
Also: as a general rule, if it's off campus, it's waaaaaay better than what's on campus.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Food Is Okay ‚Äì Tulane offers a lot of different dining options such as Panda Express, Einsteins Bagels, Sushi, Quiznos, Byblos Greek Food, Taco Bell, Smoothies, and WoW! in our student center. We also have the main dining hall and a "green" alternative cooking restaurant. Overall the food does get repetitive especially if you're a picky eater.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Some of the dorms are awful and some are very nice.
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: Campus housing is good. Depending on what dorm you live in will change the experience of housing.
Housing.Author: College Senior

Housing.Review: The rooms are not extremely spacious, but rather just enough room. The social atmospheres are enjoyable and friendly.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: The new dorms are great, the old dorms are ehh.. what do you expect?
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: Though I didn't visit other dorms, I really enjoyed my dorm, Josephine-Louise House. The entire dorm was spacious, including the rooms, which also came with a sink, mirror, refrigerator, microwave, and walk-in closet. Furthermore, though I can't say this for other dorms, my dorm was very quiet and good for studying. It also had a gigantic ballroom with great lighting for studying as well as a comfy TV room to spend time with friends. Overall, I enjoyed living in the dorm.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Depends what type of housing you're looking for. JL is a good option for freshman girls who don't want to be in a noisy, party dorm. Sharpe and Monroe are good if you want to party. Wall is a super nice, honors dorm for freshman.
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: The quality of the buildings is pretty bleh. I lived in Monroe which was the best choice just because of the social atmosphere (it's the same way in Sharp). Crappy building, bathrooms smelled bad 24/7, but I made my best friends because of living there so it was totally worth it.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Its New Orleans, so theres mold everywhere. Some dorms are way nicer than others (by a long shot).
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: The dorms on campus are kept very clean, with janitorial services cleaning the public areas daily during the week, and maintenance workers available to fix broken amenities within 24 hours when reported. However, the housing lottery is a mess. It is hard, unless you argue your way through the process, to get into a dorm you want.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Housing is fine, it's what can be expected from College dorms. Only really negative thing is the beds and maintenance.
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: It's really bad. Almost no one gets into their first choice dorm, even during sophomore year, and getting a single is almost impossible. Dorms are old, moldy, and loud. Even the "nicer" ones, such as Wall, SoHo, or Willow are not that nice when you compare them to other dorms in America. If possible, get a doctor's note so you can live off campus your sophomore year. It's much cheaper and the houses around campus are way nicer.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Depending on the building you are in, housing can be really bad or really good. Freshman housing is rough, but some of the sophomore dorms are really nice.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: The freshman dorms suck. I see people leave their snot on the elevators. I come back a few days later and the stain is still there, which proves to me that they do not clean the elevators at all. Same type of issues with the shower/bathroom. For this to be a 60,000 they can definitely step up their housing. I have been to non freshman dorms and they are somewhat nicer.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: For how much money Tulane spends they could do a great deal more on improving the freshman dorms, although it is kind of an 'experience' so to say living in a place like Monroe or Sharp.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: The dorms are definitely overpriced for their quality.  The social atmosphere is great though depending on where you live.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Housing is a pain to work with if you have any sort of problem. Some good freshmen housing options for every sort of student.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: The freshman dorm's aren't terrible, but nothing to write home about either. Sharp has awesome cabinet space but I hit my head on them every single morning. The freshman dorms mostly have communal bathrooms, and the lack of privacy sort of stinks but you learn to deal with it.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: I live in Butler, which is really central to everything I need--Bruff and PJs are right across the street, and my classes are a 5 minute walk. There's a laundry room a few feet from my dorm room which is really convenient! I chose Butler because I had heard bad things about the party dorms and while I go out, I wanted to come home to peace and quiet. Each freshman dorm has its pros and cons; it all depends on what you're looking for personally. I think no matter where you live you'll be fine, but perhaps have a different freshman experience depending on where you live.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: It would be cheaper to buy a car than to live in Tulane dorms. Not only are the exorbitant rates not worth the quality of life you are expecting, but the fact that it is a mandatory requirement to live on campus for the Freshman and Sophomore year shows that the University cares more about milking the students for their money than it does providing a wholesome college experience.
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: The social living experiences and the upkeep considering how much partying goes on is unbeatable.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: I have had the best experience in my freshmen dorm. Yes, it is small and the communal bathrooms are not ideal, but the social atmosphere is great. It is not too overwhelming; there really is not much of a problem living in a "party" dorm like Monroe or Sharp if you do not really like to party. They are not a luxury by any means, but it is a good experience. They are in good locations as well.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: good social atmosphere, many options, RAs not too strict, most have good locations, Butler, JL, and Warren are the best,
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: The size and quality of the residence hall I am in is equal to the amount of money it cost to live in it.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Almost all of Tulane's housing is what you would expect from college housing. There are party dorms, which you can often get in if you choose, and if you do not want a party dorm, there are plenty of calmer, more low-key options that you will almost definitely get if you want.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Solid. You can definitely find affordable, nice places.
Housing.Author: Recent Alumnus

Housing.Review: The housing is definitely livable, however, it is not luxurious by any stretch. The dorms are not small, but they are usually old and slightly outdated.
Housing.Author: Recent Alumnus

Housing.Review: It depends on which dorm you get in.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: My dorm was kind of old and broke a lot-washers, air conditioning, blinds. But being on campus was an overall good experience.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: I live in Deming Pavilion downtown. Great place to start out in NOLA, not the best to really experience NOLA. Windows are bolted shut "to reduce mold", ambulances come by all the time, pretty stark living conditions. BUT, really close to Tidewater, very secure, green line comes down here to Uptown campus, very close to the French Quarter.
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: Some of the dorms have cockroach problems, but I live in the newest residence, so I don't have that problem. There is a great social atmosphere. The dining hall isn't the best, but it's not bad, and there are great options in the food court (LBC). The prices of room & board and a meal plan is expensive.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: The transportation to school is horrible and the parking will be filled by the time you get here. This makes it hard to park. I rather just stay on campus.
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: I love living on Campus because everything is close. Your friends, the food, and classes are in walking distance. This saves you money because you are not using gas.
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: I live in Josephine Louise House. I love it because it is so classic! The sisterhood is amazing and living in an all girls dorm definitely has its perks.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Beautiful campus with all the amenities (the gym, an indoor and outdoor pool, many quads, the cafeteria, a health food market, an all-night every-night diner, etc.) as well as all classes within a ten minute walk from any dorm. Very nicely kept grounds. Love the live oaks. Monroe is the best social freshman dorm. Butler is arguably the worst. The housing selection process is kind of a sh*t-show every year, but in the end it all works out.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Most students are able to find places within a decent price range if they feel that's what they want to do.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: I like living on campus. It's safe and tight-knit.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Depends on where you live
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: Most of the dorms aren't anything to write home about, but there's nothing wrong with them either (Sharp and Monroe are really not that bad.) Some of the new dorms are beautiful, like SoHo and BootDorm
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: I love Wall. Great environment.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: The new dorms look like hotels, they're spectacular! The older dorms (the primarily freshman dorms) are a little out of date. But the rooms are larger than some I've seen at other schools and they tend to have a pretty social atmosphere depending on your floor.
Housing.Author: College Senior

Housing.Review: I lived in Monroe my freshman year, and it was the best experience ever! The rooms aren't the biggest or nicest, but I got super close with my floor and loved my time there. I feel Monroe had (at least my freshman year) the best balance between work and play. You could always find someone to go out with you on any given night, but you could also always find someone to stay in and watch a movie too.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: If you can pay the little bit extra, choose a nice dorm!
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: The rent is pretty cheap here. Safety is the only issue.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: On campus housing isn't fantastic, but it isn't horrible. It's a money suck, but not that different from most schools.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Freshmen love to go with sharp and monroe because they are considered the social dorms, but they are both gross. You go to a school in New Orleans so if you really want to be social, it most definitely is not hard to find. Butler is the honors dorm, but many people who aren't in the honors program live there. It is a great social dorm that is very well rounded. You won't feel bad if you do or don't go out and you can actually get decent sleep if you need it. Wall is also very nice. It's well rounded like Butler, but the rooms are much nicer and they are suite style. There is an application to get into it, but in my opinion, it's worth it. Patterson is the health and wellness dorm. I don't know many people who live there but it definitely has more of a hippie vibe
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: The residence halls are nothing extraordinary, fairly small rooms, most freshman halls have communal bathrooms and floors are split with a men's wing and women's wing. However, they do tend to have a good social atmosphere making it easy to meet a lot of people your freshman, with the exception of a few residence halls.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Some of the dorms are really nice (Wall, Patterson, Zimple, SOHO) but the freshman dorms like Monroe and Sharp are really disgusting but fun for freshmen.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Freshman dorms are gross, usually about 50 years old but have been renovated since. Monroe was fun, super social and stuff, but smaller rooms. Sharp is gross and avoid it at all costs. Butler is the freshman honors dorm, but no one wants to live there; rooms resemble those in Monroe. Wall is stereotypically the weird kids since it's the newer, nicer dorms with no communal bathrooms. Freshman dorms need more study rooms and washing machines and dryers. Sophomore dorms are generally pretty nice but there are gross ones like Warren and Paterson and Mayer. SoHo and Greenbaum and Willow are pretty nice. Aron is apartment style and it really depends on what apartment you get and who lived there before as to if it's nice or not.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Lots of places close to campus. Still live on campus so I don't know about costs and stuff.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Affordable houses that provide ample living space for 3-4 people.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Monroe is a good freshman door but there is a lot of noise and puke. Sharp is worse though. Butler is the freshman honors dorm...enough said. SOHO is nice but not so social, Irby and Phelps is old and noisy. Greenbaum is new so we'll see how it is.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Don't live off campus yet, but from what I've heard, prices close to campus are pretty high and the competition is rough (Tulane does not guarentee housing for 3 years, let alone 4)
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: freshman housing is fun but the buildings are quite wornout and not too well maintained.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: a variety of places and locations to choose from both close and far from campus. rent can be very reasonable and even at times better than paying for housing on campus.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Freshman year, Sharp is where its at. Best times I've ever had. No matter what day it is, theres a bunch of crazy fun to be found.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: There is a lot of new residence halls being built, as well as others being restored. Living on campus is very safe, and you can manage to get to your classes within 10 minutes from most residence halls. Weatherhead (SoHo), Wall, and Willow are definitely the best dorms.
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: Freshman housing isn't the most spacious or beautiful thing, but the sense of community created on the floors makes up for its shortcomings
