Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Living on campus was a great experience. I lived in one of the most social freshman dorms which was really fun. It was annoying to share a bathroom with 44 girls though and it got kinda dirty in there but they cleaned it daily. We got used to it. My sophomore year I lived in one of the nicest dorms on campus with the biggest rooms and it was awesome. I lived in a 4 person suite with my 3 best friends and we had our own bathroom. Although it was one of the less social dorms we made friends with a lot of the people on our floor anyway. Tulane also is just finishing a new dorm that's super nice.
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: Pretty much all juniors and seniors live off campus because it's nice to have your own space and not have to deal with RAs and rules. Depending on where you live the parking situation varies. My house has two driveways and street parking with a pass so there's plenty of room for us. Safety varies depending on location, but Tulane police has been putting in a big effort to help with this. Most students live pretty close to campus, but I have some friends who live a lot farther than I would be willing to walk multiple times a day.
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: There are many great opportunities to live off campus you just have to look
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: I lived in wall which is the nicest freshman dorm.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: The houses off campus are very nice and there are so many options as far as distance, size, model, etc. go. Many houses are near the shopping/food district, while others are closer to the school's campus. There are Facebook groups where people can post questions they have about housing or find possible housemates. A lot of students move off campus junior and senior years, so it is clearly very popular and feasible.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: The only downsides to off-campus housing are the increased distance from campus, the decreased level of safety, and the presence of crummy landlords. Otherwise, living off-campus is great once you're able to do it, and the majority of students choose to do so for their last two years.
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: Freshman year dorms are pretty standard, nothing special. If you live in Sharp or Monroe you'll get the typical dirty dorm experience, but in my opinion it's worth it. Sophomore year housing varies, and the option of having a single is definitely a perk (if you get a good time slot). All of the dorms are conveniently located, with the maximum walking time from one to another under 10 minutes. The vast majority of students move off campus junior year.
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: Everyone is going to tell you that you want to live in either Sharp or Monroe. Don't listen to them. The party dorms change by year anyway, and Sharp and Monroe are the two oldest and crappiest freshman dorms. Butler is advertised as honors, but you don't have to be an honors student to live there. Wall is an extra application, but it's a great community and you don't have to share a bathroom with your whole floor. JL isn't as bad as you'd think and Paterson is a great place for environmentally-minded/vegan or vegetarian people.
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: Off-campus housing can either be much cheaper than on-campus or the same cost depending on where you live. HRL has a lot of resources set up to help you move, but they don't advertise them because they want you to live on-campus. Go to their website sooner rather than later for help.
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: WAY less expensive than living off campus, and you have a lot of cool options because of the interesting architecture
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: There are some newer places to live and some older. Most of the time you will end up where you want to be as far. Only a few of the freshman dorms have sinks in the rooms which is unfortunate but as far as I know, all the sophomore dorms have them.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Most of the freshman and sophomore dorms that are considered "social" are very poorly maintained. Other dorms are much nicer, but farther from student center/ classes and considered less social.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: There are a lot of options, but it's difficult to obtain and organize signing a lease.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Most of the best places are passed down through greek life. But if you have a car its not so hard to find a nice, safe place that is easily cheaper than the dorms.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Lived in Monroe. Small,loud, stinky, old, absolutely disgusting. Over $7k to live in a double. Puke and urine all over everything. Used condoms on the flood lights. You name it. Super social and fun. But gets old FAST. There are nice dorms (like Wall and Willow) that are usually dubbed less social but new policies are allowing students who reside in them to stay there so they may be even harder to come by if thats what you're looking for. It wouldn't be so bad if we weren't forced to live here and it was actually reasonably priced.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: If you're in Greek Life, you definitely have the upper hand with off-campus housing because you can easily find a house that's been passed down through members of your sorority. If not, it's a little more difficult to find a house that's cheap, not run-down, and also near campus.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: The freshmen dorms definitely need some work, but the majority of the sophomore dorms are pretty nice. Sharp and Monroe (freshmen dorms) are not the cleanest but are awesome for meeting people.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: The dorms for the most part are ok, you can't have too many expectations as a freshman in college either way.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: I do not know because i have not looked into off campus housing yet
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: I live on campus, but I know there are many ways to find off-campus living. It's definitely cheaper too.
Housing.Author: College Senior

Housing.Review: The houses are all different and beautiful in their own ways. Everyone tries to get an off-campus house after their sophomore year.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: It really depends where you live on campus and what year you are in. Freshmen dorms are pretty average but they are very fun to live in.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: I had a great experience with because I got to live in the apartment style dorm usually reserved for juniors and seniors. However, the rooms are pretty small and I have to pay for the electricity at the end of each semester.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: all the dorms are pretty different the two typical freshman dorms Sharp and Monroe are small with communal bathrooms and not the cleanist or roomiest but its the experience I love living in them but if thats not for you there are three other two of which are honors and are very nice with one bathroom per two rooms (Wall).
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: I do not live off campus but the people that do are very pleased with their living situations
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: All the dorms have very different personalities that you can choose from.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: I don't have much experience with off campus housing, but what I've heard of is pretty good.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Tulane University has very good housing. Great atmosphere and the nicest dorms are much like a hotel.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: There are many options for juniors and seniors looking to live off campus.  Many do as Tulane does not have good on-campus options.  There is also Greek housing if you choose to join one.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Some of the freshman dorms are very dirty, loud and cramped, but overall the other residences are great. There are also a lot of options to live off campus in the immediate surrounding neighborhoods.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: People who chose to live off campus live pretty close to the school. Off-campus housing is definitely cheaper than dorm living and off campus houses are generally nicer compared to other schools.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Most of the dorms freshman year are the average square box, however sophomore and upper class housing is better.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Off campus housing is inexpensive compared to on campus.  I still would rather live on campus for all four years and get the true collegiate experience.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: On campus housing is fine but expensive.  It is cheaper to live off campus, but it is much more of a hassle.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: There are some nice apartments near campus but you typically need connections to ensure one.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: I don't really know that much about off-campus housing. But I have heard the living conditions are less than ideal.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: I just finished my first you, so my exposure is limited.  I stayed in an all girls freshman dorm which is the oldest on campus.  It came with a sink in the room and a decent size walk-in closet.  The other dorms are much newer and more modern.  Close to classroom buildings, etc.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: New Orleans has tons of apartments and houses for rent in all different areas!
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: It's very close to campus. However, too difficult to find.
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: Weatherhead and Aron and Wall are all pretty nice dorms.
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: The freshman dorms are just average, but the upperclassmen dorms are really great and convenient.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review:
Best:
Willow
Weatherhead
Aron
Phelps/Irby (if you want social)
Wall
Worst:
Monroe
Sharp
Butler
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: There are many houses around campus available to rent. Finding one to live in can be a challenge sometimes because student are already living in them! You have to be strategic in getting one and make sure you find a place where someone is going to be moving out and will let you take up the lease after theirs. But it is easier to find a room in a house if you're just looking for a place for yourself. It's only harder when you want a house for you and specific other people. The places available vary in price, but they're close and convenient. Uptown New Orleans is pretty compact.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: I currently live on campus, which I think is the best option for Freshman through Juniors, but there are many houses available for rent within a few miles of campus. If you can shack up with a few friends, it is relatively easy to find a place to rent nearby. The only problem is the cost, because I know for a nice place it can get pricey. The houses in New Orleans are nice, and there are some very expensive neighborhoods in uptown.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: The dorms at the school are pretty good. We have co-ed dorms and we have an all girls dorm. The dorms are in good condition and the bed are pretty comfortable.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Freshmen housing options are fairly simple. Sharp and Monroe are the larger freshmen dorms, ideal for social people looking to be around lots of people. Paterson and JL (all girls) are smaller dorms with more amenities and are a bit more quiet. It is possible to have fun and an active social life in any of the dorms however. The pricing on residence hall renting is a bit ridiculous so upperclassmen should look to find off-campus housing as soon as possible.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: The two main freshman dorms are Sharp and Monroe. The rooms are pretty typical of a college dorm, but the social atmosphere is the best. Dorms such as Wall, Warren, and Butler allow freshman and have nice rooms, but aren't considered as "fun."
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Freshman dorms: Monroe, Sharp, Butler, Wall, Paterson, JL, Warren (2012-2013 year). The first 3 are old and somewhat run down, but they really aren't that bad and are the most social of the dorms. Wall JL and Paterson are nice and have bigger rooms. Either way, the rooms aren't cramped, the bathrooms aren't too awful, and the elevators work most of the time. Dorm living your freshman year is an experience, enjoy it.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Mostly students rent houses around Tulane with several of their friends. Typically they are fairly nice and close to campus, but you have to be careful because it is New Orleans and there are areas that could be unsafe for students to live, even if they are fairly close to campus.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Even though I am not in the honors program, I live in the freshmen honors housing. I love it here! The rooms are your typical dorm rooms...small. The exposed brick walls are really cute though! The bathrooms are kept clean, which is really nice. There are codes to the bathrooms, which keep members of the opposite sex out. You don't have to worry about getting out of the shower and seeing a guy in there. I am conveniently right by the gym and the dining hall! I'm really happy I don't live in the party dorms: monroe and sharp.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Can be difficult to find. Rooms go very quickly, especially if they are reasonably priced. Expect to pay at least $500/month on rent alone if you are lucky. Most I have seen are at least $600/month if it is close to campus. I do love having a place to get away from school. On campus parking is very expensive, so it is worth not having to buy a parking permit.
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: The only good thing about off-campus housing is that it is affordable. No matter how much you are willing to spend there are nothing luxurious are even nice available to rent near campus. Places are generally crammed together and old, so get used to hearing everything going on around you and don't expect much privacy. If you can afford it, buy a house and rent it out to good friends.
Housing.Author: College Senior

Housing.Review: Plenty of Close Options ‚Äì Parking can be somewhat tricky, as ticketing is common.  Living off campus can be much cheaper than living on campus, especially if you are willing to live with a couple housemates.  Most food expenses are significantly lower for those living off campus, as you are not required to purchase a meal plan and meal plans are extremely expensive. Safety can be issue, especially at night.
Housing.Author: College Senior

Housing.Review: Don't Believe Everything You Hear ‚Äì Almost every freshman entering Tulane requested to be in Monroe or Sharp, according to the housing office. I was placed in JL, after my application to another dorm was lost (which is why I gave a B, the housing process leaves something to be desired). However, once there I found a very welcoming atmosphere and the girls on my floor became very close; it was also much, much cleaner than Sharp or Monroe. Besides Wall, I think it is one of the most enjoyable housing options available to freshman. The options for upperclassmen are much better, however, with new dorms like Weatherhead and alternative options like the apartment-style living of Willow.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Housing options that cater to your needs/preferences.  All girls dorm, co-ed dorms, health and wellness dorm, upperclassman dorms.
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: Its Pretty Good ‚Äì They offer it to you along with on campus housing. They explain everything for you and provide great details so that you make your choice.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Things Are Decent ‚Äì The dorms at Tulane are decent to good. Some, like Monroe and sharp, are for college freshman in New Orleans. So they are party dorms, with things getting broken all the time, plus they are rather dirty. Other dorms, such as Willow and Wall, are much nicer. They have kitchens, laundry rooms, lounges, and more on every floor. Plus you have your bathroom and sink. They are also well kept, and just overall very nice. They are slightly farther from classes, but still nothing that bad.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Large Variety ‚Äì Each freshmen dorm on campus is very unique so you can find what you are looking for. Some people want something super social but the dorm isn't the cleanest-Sharp/Monroe, some people want to be around really smart kids but it might not be the most social-Butler, some may want really nice rooms with their own bathroom but again, it's not very social-Wall. There is also JL-all girls dorm, and Patterson-wellness dorm.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Decent Housing Options ‚Äì Freshmen and sophomores are required to live on campus. Living on campus is super convenient and easy. The quality of the freshmen dorms are typically of most other colleges, unless you live in Wall or JL.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Live Close to Campus With Ease! Most juniors and seniors live off-campus.  Boys can live in their fraternity houses, but the girls are not allowed to live in sorority houses due to a Louisiana law.  Many upperclassmen live in houses they share with multiple students near campus.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Not Knowledgable ‚Äì I'm a freshman and intend to live on-campus next year. I do know that many students are able to find houses for a relatively good price. Tulane does host an off-campus housing fair.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Living on Campus as a Freshman ‚Äì I am a freshman and I live in JL(All Girls Dorm) and I absolutely love it. Over the summer the rooms were freshly painted and equipped with new furniture not to mention the rooms are huge compared to the rooms in other co-ed dorms. The showers are also more personal including a space to dress and un-dress. It was also close to a lot of my classes this semester. The only downfall is that it is the farthest dorm so it is a walk but you get use to it fast. As far as the other freshman dorms (sharp & monroe) I would say they are okay nothing special, livable.  I would label the honors dorm wall as the best and if you have time apply to live in these dorms it's well worth it. Sharp & Monroe are more of the party dorms but JL is still very social.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Housing quality varies greatly at Tulane. The freshman dorms are fairly unattractive, but the options significantly improve with class standing. The cost is relatively expensive and makes living off-campus an appealing alternative; many juniors and seniors chose to live off-campus. The majority of the dorms are centrally located and within a 10 minute walking distance to all academic and social buildings.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Off campus housing usually comes in the form of rented houses. While you can find a place Downtown near the French Quarter, most students stay in the more upperclass uptown area that the campus itself is in. Broadway (the road that runs parallel to the university) contains most of the off campus houses and most of the Fraternity an Sorority housing. There are a bunch of great off campus options in the Uptown area which is the safest place to be in new orleans. Things may get pricy but its easy to find roommates to defer the cost.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Residential Colleges ‚Äì Joining Wall Residential College = big rooms, diverse (not just culturally speaking), and better than the other Freshman dorms. I love it here. Well worth the application.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Plenty of Apartments ‚Äì As the title says, there are at least five apartment communities in close proximity to the school branch campus here in Biloxi Ms' each with varying amenities and conveniences.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Dorms are ok not great. Slightly on the costly side if you ask me.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Cheap Scarce Close ‚Äì not much houses are in alright conditions but relatively cheap and close to campus
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Some of the dorms are nice, and some are bad. The amenities are good, it's very expensive.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: On campus housing isn't the best in the world, but it could be worse. Living on campus is required for freshman and sophomores. Neither of the two main freshman dorms (Sharp and Monroe) is anything close to luxury, but both are very social and fun, and will help you meet people who will be your best friends. Irby and Phelps are the two most popular sophomore buildings, which are a bit of an eye-sore, looking like motels. However, this campus housing makes up for the lack of fraternity and sorority house by giving students the opportunity to live in suites of eight people sharing a bathroom. Another popular option for sophomores in Mayor which have suites of singles and doubles. Upper classmen housing isnt great, but is offset by the gorgeous, plentiful and cheep off-campus housing must students chose instead.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review:
Lots of Options ‚Äì In uptown New Orleans, you can find some of the most beautiful houses in the city, and some of them are inhabited by Tulane students--though many house more students than can be counted on one hand. These many-student houses can be great, though they often become more like a "frat house," and they're never cheap. 
At the same time, you can find a "room" (read: bed and some space) in an apartment for under $400 a month, you just wouldn't really want to live there. And of course, there's everything in between. If you look hard enough, you'll find something you can be happy with.
Housing.Author: Recent Alumnus

Housing.Review: Student Friendly Campus in Beautiful New Orleans ‚Äì Tulane's campus is in the heart of Uptown New Orleans and is surrounded by a diverse selection of restaurants, bars, and boutiques.  The campus itself has been undergoing a bit of updating, starting with the University Center in 2003.  Slowly Tulane has been working to update and renovate the dorms, as well as increase the number of on-campus housing options for students.  All of the dorms are centered around Bruff Commons, which is the main dining hall on campus and houses the mail room and student mail boxes.  As much as your budget will allow, skip the dining hall and explore the amazing restaurants of New Orleans - there are tons of cafes and restaurants within walking distance that can cure any culinary craving you might have!  The city was made for people who love to eat, drink, and be merry!  There are grassy quads to hang out in and lay out to enjoy the warm, sunny New Orleans weather, and a large city park right across the street from the main campus.  When I enrolled at Tulane, the housing process my freshman year was extremely easy, and I was paired up with another girl who still is one of my closest friends.  Going into sophomore year, the drafting process to sign up for housing was a little trickier, but it still worked out well for my friends out, and we got our top pick.
Housing.Author: Recent Alumnus

Housing.Review:
Must Do, Even If You Don't Want to ‚Äì The campus is located in a residential area, surrounded on three sides by houses, most of which are available for rent, so there's no problem finding a place. Rent is pretty good, although it's determined by house so it depends on how many roommates you have. A average shotgun house runs about $1200 a month, so if you have 2 roommates with you that's a cheap $400 a month, which is actually something like the average rent around the area.
Thing is, if you want to stay on campus, you can't. There's no guaranteed housing for juniors and seniors, and even the sophomores who have guaranteed housing run a risk of being thrown off campus because there's just not enough space for even all the freshmen and sophomores. Staying on campus all four years is not really an option unless you're really, really lucky or an RA.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Josephine Louise ‚Äì I live the all girl dorm making it hard to meet people of the opposite sex if you are an introvert. It is a beautiful dorm though and the rooms are really spacious. The bathrooms are always clean and you never have to worry about all the showers being taken.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: All freshman and the vast majority of sophomores live on-campus. Off-campus housing is available and you can find relatively cheap apartments and houses to rent, however there really isn't a big need to move off-campus as housing is available for all students.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Deming is not a place you live. Though it is conveniently located near Tidewater, the windows don't open, and roaches never go away, the rooms are tiny, and there's no social atmosphere.
Housing.Author: Recent Alumnus

Housing.Review:
Housing around the Tulane campus varies in cost and quality. The Broadway side of campus, where the fraternities and sororities are located, tends to be more expensive and noisy, but also the most lively and social. A lot of the apartments and houses look like dumps from the outside, but are actually have fully renovated interiors. Watch out for crazy landlords though! Most tend to work at the laid back pace that gives New Orleans its charm, but are miserable to work with when the AC breaks...

Also, a lot of apartments are unofficially "handed down" from upperclassmen to their younger friends (especially in frats and sororities). Although it is not that hard to find an apartment in the area if you start looking early enough, this saves a lot of work. A lot of seniors are often trying to get rid of furniture, so you could end up with a fully furnished apartment for a few hundred dollars!
Housing.Author: Recent Alumnus
